name: Grapefruit
description: Grapefruit is a large, round citrus fruit with a yellow-orange rind and juicy, acidic flesh that can range from white to pink to ruby red. Known for its tart to semi-sweet flavor and high vitamin C content.

name: Lemons
description: Lemons are bright yellow citrus fruits with a sour, acidic taste. They're widely used for their juice and zest in cooking, baking, beverages, and as a natural flavoring agent.

name: Limes
description: Limes are small, green citrus fruits with a distinctive tart and tangy flavor. They're commonly used in various cuisines worldwide for beverages, desserts, and culinary applications.

name: Mandarins (inc clementines & similar hybrids)
description: Mandarins are small citrus fruits with loose, easy-to-peel skin and sweet segments. This category includes clementines, tangerines, satsumas and similar hybrid varieties.

name: Oranges
description: Oranges are round citrus fruits with a bright orange peel and juicy, sweet to slightly tart segmented flesh. They're valued for their high vitamin C content and versatile culinary uses.

name: Pomelos
description: Pomelos are the largest citrus fruit, with a thick pale green or yellow rind and sweet-tart flesh that resembles a mild, less bitter grapefruit. Native to Southeast Asia and an ancestor of modern grapefruit.

name: Other citrus fruits
description: Various other citrus fruits not specifically categorized elsewhere, which may include kumquats, citrons, bergamots, and other less common citrus varieties.

name: Almonds including ground almonds
description: Almonds are tree nuts with a characteristic sweet flavor, available in whole, sliced, chopped forms or ground into flour. They're rich in protein, healthy fats, and vitamin E.

name: Apricot kernels
description: Apricot kernels are the seed found inside the stone of apricots. They have a bitter almond-like flavor and contain compounds that should be consumed with caution due to amygdalin content.

name: Brazil nuts
description: Brazil nuts are large, crescent-shaped nuts native to South America. They're known for their creamy texture, rich flavor, and exceptionally high selenium content.

name: Cashew nuts
description: Cashews are kidney-shaped nuts with a sweet, buttery flavor and creamy texture. They're widely used in culinary applications and for making dairy alternatives like cashew milk and cheese.

name: Chestnuts
description: Chestnuts are large, starchy tree nuts with a distinctive sweet flavor when roasted. Unlike most nuts, they're low in fat and protein but high in carbohydrates and fiber.

name: Coconut - fresh
description: Fresh coconut refers to the white flesh (meat) of mature coconuts. It has a sweet, nutty flavor and firm texture, used in both savory and sweet dishes across tropical cuisines.

name: Coconut - desiccated, dried, flour
description: Processed forms of coconut meat including desiccated (finely shredded and dried), dried flakes, and coconut flour which is made from dried, defatted coconut meat and is gluten-free.

name: Coconut juice, milk, cream or water
description: Liquid products derived from coconuts, including coconut water from young coconuts, coconut milk and cream made by pressing grated coconut meat with water.

name: Coconut - other products (yoghurt etc.)
description: Various coconut-derived food products including coconut yogurt, ice cream, butter, and other processed foods that use coconut as a primary ingredient.

name: Hazelnuts
description: Hazelnuts, also known as filberts, are round nuts with a rich, sweet flavor that intensifies when roasted. They're commonly used in confectionery, particularly chocolate products, and in baking.

name: Macadamia nuts
description: Macadamia nuts are smooth, round nuts native to Australia with an exceptionally buttery texture and rich flavor. They have the highest fat content among commercial nuts.

name: Pecans
description: Pecans are native to North America with a rich, buttery flavor and distinctive elongated shape. They're commonly used in sweet dishes, especially pecan pie, and as a snack.

name: Pine nuts
description: Pine nuts are small, elongated seeds harvested from various species of pine cones. They have a delicate sweet, nutty flavor and are essential in dishes like pesto and many Mediterranean recipes.

name: Pistachios
description: Pistachios are small nuts with a distinctive green color and sweet, earthy flavor. They're commonly sold in-shell with their characteristic split revealing the edible kernel inside.

name: Walnuts
description: Walnuts have a wrinkled, two-lobed appearance resembling a brain. They offer a mild, earthy flavor with slight bitterness and are rich in omega-3 fatty acids and antioxidants.

name: Other tree nuts & mixed nuts
description: Various other tree nuts not specifically categorized elsewhere, including lesser-known varieties and commercial nut mixes containing multiple types of nuts.

name: Nut spreads and butters (except peanut)
description: Creamy spreads made from ground tree nuts such as almond butter, cashew butter, and other nut butters excluding peanut butter (as peanuts are legumes, not tree nuts).

name: Apples - fresh or dried
description: Apples are round or oval pome fruits with firm, crisp flesh and skin that varies in color. Available in numerous varieties with flavors ranging from sweet to tart, consumed fresh or dried.

name: Pears - fresh
description: Fresh pears are sweet, juicy pome fruits with a characteristic bell shape and flesh that ranges from crisp to soft depending on ripeness and variety. They come in multiple varieties with different flavors and textures.

name: Quinces
description: Quinces are fragrant pome fruits resembling a cross between apples and pears but with tough flesh that is typically too astringent to eat raw and is commonly cooked in preserves, jellies and desserts.

name: Medlars
description: Medlars are unusual pome fruits that become edible only after 'bletting' (softening by frost or time). They have a brown, apple-like appearance with a rich, date-like flavor when ripe.

name: Loquats
description: Loquats are small, yellow-orange pome fruits with sweet-tart flesh and a few large seeds. Native to China, they're often eaten fresh or made into jellies and preserves.

name: Other pome fruit
description: Various other pome fruits not specifically categorized elsewhere, including less common varieties and hybrids in the Rosaceae family with a core of several small seeds.

name: Apricots - fresh
description: Fresh apricots are small, golden-orange stone fruits with velvety skin and sweet-tart flesh. They have a short seasonal availability and are valued for their distinctive flavor.

name: Cherries - fresh or dried
description: Cherries are small, round stone fruits with a single pit, available in sweet and sour varieties. They range in color from bright red to deep burgundy, and can be consumed fresh or dried.

name: Peaches (& similar hybrids)
description: Peaches are fuzzy-skinned stone fruits with juicy, sweet flesh that can be yellow or white. This category includes similar hybrids like pluots, apriums and peacotums.

name: Plums - fresh
description: Fresh plums are juicy stone fruits that come in various colors from yellow to red to purple-black. They have smooth skin and sweet to tart flesh surrounding a single pit.

name: Nectarines
description: Nectarines are smooth-skinned stone fruits closely related to peaches but lacking the fuzzy exterior. They have sweet, juicy flesh that can be yellow or white, with a rich aroma.

name: Other stone fruit
description: Various other fruits with a large central stone or pit not specifically categorized elsewhere, including less common varieties and hybrids within the Prunus genus.

name: Table grapes
description: Table grapes are cultivated specifically for fresh consumption. They typically have thin skin, sweet juicy flesh, and can be seedless or contain seeds. Available in a range of colors from green to red to black.

name: Wine grapes
description: Wine grapes are smaller and sweeter than table grapes with thicker skins and higher seed content. They're specifically grown for wine production and are rarely consumed fresh.

name: Strawberries - fresh or dried
description: Strawberries are bright red berries with tiny seeds on their exterior surface. They have a sweet, slightly acidic flavor and distinctive aroma, available fresh or dried.

name: Blackberries
description: Blackberries are aggregate fruits composed of small drupelets. They have a deep purple-black color when ripe with a sweet-tart flavor and are rich in antioxidants.

name: Dewberries
description: Dewberries are closely related to blackberries but grow on trailing vines rather than erect canes. They tend to be smaller, shinier, and have fewer but larger drupelets than blackberries.

name: Loganberries, boysenberries and other hybrids
description: Various hybrid berries including loganberries (raspberry-blackberry hybrid) and boysenberries (complex hybrid of raspberry, blackberry, dewberry, and loganberry). They typically have complex, rich flavors.

name: Raspberries
description: Raspberries are aggregate fruits composed of small drupelets arranged in a hollow core. Most commonly red, but also available in black, purple, and golden varieties with sweet-tart flavor.

name: Other cane fruit
description: Various berries that grow on canes not specifically categorized elsewhere, including lesser-known varieties and regional specialties from the Rubus genus.

name: Blueberries - fresh or dried
description: Blueberries are small, round berries with a blue to purple-black color and sweet flavor. They can be consumed fresh or dried and are noted for their high antioxidant content.

name: Cranberries - fresh or dried
description: Cranberries are small, red berries with a very tart, acidic flavor. Often processed with sugar for consumption, they're available fresh or dried and commonly used in sauces, juices, and baked goods.

name: Currants (black, red, white)
description: Currants are small berries that grow in clusters on shrubs. They come in black, red, and white varieties with varying levels of sweetness and tartness, commonly used in preserves and baking.

name: Goji berries (wolfberry) - fresh or dried
description: Goji berries are small, red berries native to Asia with a slight sweet-tart flavor. Usually consumed dried, they're marketed as a 'superfood' due to their nutrient content.

name: Gooseberries
description: Gooseberries are small, translucent berries with pronounced veining and a fuzzy surface. They range from green to red or purple when ripe, with a tart flavor that sweetens as they mature.

name: Rosehips
description: Rosehips are the fruit of rose plants, typically red to orange in color. They have a tangy, slightly sweet flavor and are rich in vitamin C, commonly used in teas, jams, and supplements.

name: Mulberries
description: Mulberries are multiple fruits resembling elongated blackberries. They can be white, red, or dark purple-black when ripe, with a sweet flavor that varies in intensity by variety.

name: Azarole (mediterranean medlar)
description: Azarole, also known as Mediterranean medlar, is a small red or yellow fruit resembling a small apple. It has a sweet-tart flavor and is used in preserves, liqueurs, and eaten fresh in Mediterranean regions.

name: Elderberries
description: Elderberries are small, dark purple-black berries that grow in clusters. They have a tart, slightly bitter flavor when raw and must be cooked before consumption. Commonly used in syrups, wines, and medicinal preparations.

name: Other small fruit & berries
description: Various other small fruits and berries not specifically categorized elsewhere, including lesser-known varieties, regional specialties, and newer cultivated hybrids.

name: Vine fruits - currants
description: Dried currants are small, dark, sweet dried fruits made from a specific type of small grape. They're smaller than raisins and commonly used in baking, particularly in traditional holiday foods.

name: Vine fruits - raisins
description: Raisins are dried grapes, typically from larger grape varieties. They have a dark color, chewy texture, and concentrated sweet flavor, commonly used in baking, cereals, and snack foods.

name: Vine fruits - sultanas
description: Sultanas are dried white grapes, typically softer, sweeter and lighter in color than regular raisins. They're particularly popular in European and Middle Eastern cuisines for both sweet and savory dishes.

name: Apricots - dried
description: Dried apricots are preserved apricot fruits with concentrated flavor and nutrients. They have a chewy texture and intensely sweet-tart taste, available in natural brown color or treated with sulfur for orange appearance.

name: Dates - dried
description: Dried dates are sweet, energy-dense fruits with a caramel-like flavor. They vary in size, color and texture depending on variety, with common types including Medjool, Deglet Noor, and Barhi.

name: Figs - dried
description: Dried figs are preserved fig fruits with a chewy texture and concentrated sweet flavor with characteristic crunchy seeds. They come in several varieties including Black Mission, Turkish, and Calimyrna.

name: Papaya - dried
description: Dried papaya consists of preserved pieces of tropical papaya fruit. Often candied or sugar-coated, it has a chewy texture and sweet flavor, commonly used in trail mixes and as a snack.

name: Pears - dried
description: Dried pears are preserved pear fruits with concentrated sweetness and a chewy texture. They retain the characteristic pear flavor and are often used in fruit mixes, baking, and as a standalone snack.

name: Pineapple - dried
description: Dried pineapple consists of preserved pieces of tropical pineapple fruit. It has an intensely sweet flavor with characteristic tropical notes, often available candied or with added sugar.

name: Prunes - dried plums
description: Prunes are dried plums with a deep, sweet flavor and chewy texture. They're known for their digestive health benefits and are used in both sweet and savory dishes across various cuisines.

name: Tomatoes - dried (sundried, sunblush)
description: Dried tomatoes are preserved tomato fruits with intensified umami and slightly sweet flavor. They have a chewy texture and concentrated taste, commonly used in Mediterranean cuisine and as flavor enhancers.

name: Other dried or candied fruits and mixed dried fruits
description: Various other dried or candied fruits and fruit mixes not specifically categorized elsewhere, including tropical fruits, berries, and specialty items that have been preserved through dehydration.

name: Dried vegetables - various
description: Various vegetables that have been preserved through dehydration, including dried mushrooms, peppers, carrots, onions, and other vegetables used for cooking, soups, and other culinary applications.

name: Carambola (star fruit)
description: Carambola or star fruit is a tropical fruit with a distinctive star shape when cut crosswise. It has a crisp, juicy texture with flavor ranging from sweet to tart depending on ripeness.

name: Dates - fresh
description: Fresh dates are sweet fruits with a chewy texture and rich flavor. They range in color from bright red to bright yellow when unripe, maturing to brown as they ripen and dry naturally on the tree.

name: Dragonfruit (pitahaya)
description: Dragonfruit is a tropical fruit with a bright pink or yellow exterior and white or red flesh speckled with tiny black seeds. It has a mildly sweet taste and soft texture similar to kiwi fruit.

name: Figs - fresh
description: Fresh figs are soft, pear-shaped fruits with edible seeds and skin. They have a sweet taste and unique texture with a combination of smoothness from the flesh and crunch from the seeds.

name: Jambolan (java plum)
description: Jambolan, also known as java plum or jamun, is a small, purple to black berry-like fruit. It has a sweet-sour taste that can be astringent, with a single seed surrounded by purple flesh.

name: Kumquats
description: Kumquats are small citrus fruits that can be eaten whole with their sweet, edible skin and tart flesh. They resemble tiny oranges and are often consumed fresh or preserved in syrups or marmalades.

name: Olives (table consumption)
description: Table olives are processed olives intended for direct consumption, not oil production. They come in various colors (green, black, purple) and preparations including brined, stuffed, and marinated varieties.

name: Persimmon - fresh or dried
description: Persimmons are orange fruits with a sweet, honey-like flavor when fully ripe. The two main types are astringent (heart-shaped Hachiya) and non-astringent (tomato-shaped Fuyu), available both fresh and dried.

name: Other misc. fruit - edible peel
description: Various other fruits with edible peels not specifically categorized elsewhere, including lesser-known tropical and temperate fruits where the skin is commonly consumed along with the flesh.

name: American persimmon (Virginia kaki)
description: American persimmon is a small, orange fruit native to eastern United States. It has extremely astringent flesh until fully ripened, at which point it develops a rich, sweet flavor with notes of honey and apricot.

name: Kiwi fruit - fresh or dried
description: Kiwi fruit has brown fuzzy skin and bright green flesh with tiny black seeds. It has a unique sweet-tart flavor and can be eaten fresh (peeled) or dried. Rich in vitamin C and dietary fiber.

name: Longans
description: Longans are small, round fruits with translucent white flesh and a black seed. Related to lychee but smaller and less aromatic, they have a light, sweet flavor and are often eaten fresh after removing the thin brown shell.

name: Litchis (lychee)
description: Lychees are small fruits with rough, red inedible skin and sweet, fragrant white flesh surrounding a single seed. They have a distinct floral flavor and are often eaten fresh or used in desserts and beverages.

name: Passion fruit, granadilla, maracujá
description: Passion fruits are small, round or oval fruits with tough outer rinds containing juicy, seed-filled pulp. They have an intensely aromatic, sweet-tart flavor used in beverages, desserts, and culinary applications.

name: Prickly pear
description: Prickly pear is the fruit of the Opuntia cactus with a spiny exterior that must be removed before consumption. The interior flesh can be various colors with a sweet, melon-like flavor containing numerous tiny, hard seeds.

name: Rambutans
description: Rambutans are tropical fruits with a red, hairy exterior that must be removed to reveal the translucent, sweet flesh inside. Related to lychees and longans, they have a sweet, slightly acidic flavor.

name: Star apple
description: Star apple is a tropical fruit with purple or green skin and sweet, milky white flesh that forms a star pattern when cut crosswise. It has a mild, sweet taste with a subtle floral character.

name: Tamarillo
description: Tamarillo, also called tree tomato, is an egg-shaped fruit with smooth skin that can be red, orange, or yellow. It has tart flesh with numerous edible seeds and a flavor resembling tomato and passion fruit.

name: Other misc. fruit - inedible peel, small
description: Various other small fruits with inedible peels not specifically categorized elsewhere, including lesser-known tropical and specialty fruits where the skin is typically removed before consumption.

name: Avocados
description: Avocados are large fruits with green to black inedible skin and creamy, pale green flesh surrounding a large seed. They have a rich, buttery texture and mild flavor, high in healthy fats and nutrients.

name: Bananas & plantains
description: Bananas are sweet, elongated fruits with yellow peel when ripe. Plantains are similar but starchier, less sweet, and typically cooked before eating. Both are botanically berries with inedible peels.

name: Bread fruit
description: Breadfruit is a large, starchy tropical fruit with green, bumpy inedible skin. When cooked, its pale flesh has a texture similar to bread and a potato-like flavor, serving as a staple food in many tropical regions.

name: Cherimoya
description: Cherimoya is a heart-shaped tropical fruit with green, scale-patterned inedible skin. Its creamy white flesh has a unique sweet flavor often described as a blend of banana, pineapple, and strawberry.

name: Durian
description: Durian is a large tropical fruit with a thorny exterior and distinctive strong odor. Its creamy, custard-like flesh has a complex flavor profile that fans describe as rich and sweet while others find off-putting.

name: Guava - fresh or dried
description: Guavas are tropical fruits with edible but often removed skin and aromatic flesh that can be white, pink, yellow, or red. They have a sweet, musky flavor with notes of pear and strawberry, available fresh or dried.

name: Mangoes - fresh or dried
description: Mangoes are juicy tropical fruits with inedible skin that ranges from green to yellow to red. The sweet, aromatic orange flesh surrounds a large flat seed and can be consumed fresh or dried.

name: Papaya (pawpaw)
description: Papaya is a large tropical fruit with yellow-orange skin and sweet, juicy orange flesh containing numerous black seeds. It has a mild, sweet flavor with musky undertones and a soft, butter-like consistency when ripe.

name: Pineapples
description: Pineapples are large tropical fruits with tough, spiky inedible skin and sweet-tart yellow flesh. They have a distinctive sweet and acidic flavor with complex tropical notes, often eaten fresh or used in cooking.

name: Pomegranates
description: Pomegranates are round fruits with tough, leathery red skin containing hundreds of juicy, gem-like arils (seed sacs). These seeds have a sweet-tart flavor and bright ruby color, often consumed fresh or as juice.

name: Soursop (guanabana)
description: Soursop is a large, heart-shaped tropical fruit with spiny green inedible skin. Its creamy white flesh has a unique sweet-sour flavor often described as a combination of strawberry and pineapple with citrus notes.

name: Other misc. fruit - inedible peel, large
description: Various other large fruits with inedible peels not specifically categorized elsewhere, including lesser-known tropical fruits and specialty varieties where the skin is typically removed before consumption.

name: Early potatoes
description: Early potatoes are young potatoes harvested before full maturity, typically in spring or early summer. They have thin, delicate skins, a waxy texture, and sweeter flavor than mature potatoes.

name: Ware potatoes
description: Ware potatoes are mature potatoes grown for general consumption rather than seed or processing. They include various varieties with different characteristics suitable for different cooking methods.

name: Cassava, manioc, tapioca and products
description: Cassava is a starchy root vegetable and major food staple in tropical regions. Used to make tapioca and various products, it must be properly processed before consumption to remove naturally occurring toxins.

name: Dasheen, taro & eddoes
description: These are starchy root vegetables popular in tropical cuisines. Taro (dasheen) has a mild, nutty flavor while eddoes are smaller varieties. All must be cooked to neutralize calcium oxalate crystals before consumption.

name: Sweet potatoes
description: Sweet potatoes are tuberous root vegetables with orange, yellow, purple, or white flesh. They have a sweet flavor that intensifies when cooked and are nutritionally dense with high vitamin A content in orange varieties.

name: Yams
description: True yams are starchy tubers distinct from sweet potatoes, with rough, scaly skin and starchy, dry flesh. They're staple foods in many tropical regions and come in varieties ranging in color from white to purple to pink.

name: Other tropical root & tuber vegetables
description: Various other tropical root and tuber vegetables not specifically categorized elsewhere, including lesser-known varieties particular to certain regions and cultures with diverse culinary applications.

name: Beetroot
description: Beetroot is a root vegetable with deep purple-red flesh and sweet, earthy flavor. Rich in nutrients and natural pigments called betalains, it's used in salads, soups, juices, and as a natural food coloring.

name: Carrots
description: Carrots are root vegetables typically orange in color, though purple, black, red, white, and yellow varieties exist. They have a sweet, earthy flavor and crisp texture, consumed both raw and cooked.

name: Celeriac
description: Celeriac is the root of a celery variety grown specifically for its large, bulbous root rather than stalks. It has a knobby exterior, white flesh, and a mild celery-like flavor with nutty undertones.

name: Chicory (root)
description: Chicory root is a woody root often roasted and ground as a coffee substitute or additive. It has a bitter-sweet flavor and is used in traditional European cooking as well as in processed food products.

name: Jerusalem artichokes
description: Jerusalem artichokes, also called sunchokes, are knobby tubers of a sunflower species. They have a crisp texture when raw and a sweet, nutty flavor similar to artichokes when cooked, despite being unrelated to true artichokes.

name: Parsnips
description: Parsnips are cream-colored root vegetables shaped like carrots with a sweet, nutty flavor that intensifies when cooked. They're particularly popular in winter cooking and traditionally used in roasts and stews.

name: Parsley root
description: Parsley root comes from a variety of parsley grown for its edible taproot rather than its leaves. It resembles a small parsnip with a flavor combining celery, parsley, and carrots, commonly used in Central and Eastern European cuisines.

name: Radishes incl. daikon
description: Radishes are crisp root vegetables with flavors ranging from mild to peppery. They come in various shapes, sizes, and colors, from small red round varieties to long white daikon radishes popular in Asian cuisine.

name: Salsify
description: Salsify is a root vegetable with long, thin roots and oyster-like flavor when cooked (hence its nickname 'oyster plant'). Black salsify has dark skin with white flesh, while white salsify has lighter coloration.

name: Swedes and rutabaga
description: Swedes (called rutabaga in North America) are large, round root vegetables with yellow flesh and a sweet, earthy flavor. They are a cross between cabbage and turnip, typically used in stews, soups, and roasted dishes.

name: Turnips
description: Turnips are root vegetables with white flesh and a purple-tinged top. They have a mild, slightly sweet and peppery flavor when young, becoming more pronounced as they mature. Both roots and greens are edible.

name: Other temperate root & tuber vegetables
description: Various other root and tuber vegetables grown in temperate climates not specifically categorized elsewhere, including lesser-known varieties with diverse culinary applications.

name: Garlic, fresh, powder and paste
description: Garlic in various forms including fresh bulbs, dried powder, and processed paste. Known for its pungent aroma and flavor, it's used as a key seasoning ingredient in cuisines worldwide.

name: Onions
description: Onions are bulb vegetables with layered structure and pungent aroma that sweetens when cooked. They come in various colors (yellow, white, red) and sizes, serving as a fundamental flavoring base in cuisines globally.

name: Shallots
description: Shallots are small bulb vegetables related to onions but with a milder, more delicate flavor. They typically grow in clusters and have copper-colored thin skin with purple-tinged white flesh, valued in gourmet cooking.

name: Spring onions, Welsh onions, scallions
description: Young onions harvested before the bulb fully develops, with long green shoots and a small white bulb. They have a milder, fresher flavor than mature onions and are often used raw or lightly cooked.

name: Other bulb vegetables
description: Various other vegetables grown for their edible bulbs not specifically categorized elsewhere, including specialty varieties like ramps, pearl onions, and other members of the Allium family.

name: Aubergines (egg plant, brinjal)
description: Aubergines are glossy, purple-skinned vegetables with creamy flesh and a mild, somewhat bitter flavor that becomes rich when cooked. They absorb flavors well and are used in cuisines worldwide, particularly Mediterranean and Asian.

name: Pepinos
description: Pepinos are yellow-green to gold fruits with purple striping and smooth skin. They have a sweet, mild flavor often compared to a blend of cucumber and honeydew melon, sometimes called pepino melon or melon pear.

name: Peppers (sweet or bell) - fresh or dried
description: Bell peppers are crisp, mild-flavored vegetables that come in various colors (green, red, yellow, orange). They have a sweet, non-spicy taste and are used both fresh and dried in countless dishes worldwide.

name: Chilli peppers - fresh or dried
description: Chili peppers are spicy varieties that contain capsaicin. They range widely in heat levels and flavors, from mild to extremely hot, and are used both fresh and dried in many global cuisines as flavoring agents.

name: Tomatoes
description: Tomatoes are red or yellow fruiting vegetables with juicy flesh and numerous seeds. They have a balance of sweetness and acidity and come in numerous varieties from tiny cherry tomatoes to large beefsteak types.

name: Tomatillo (ground cherry)
description: Tomatillos are small, green fruits encased in a papery husk. They have a tart, citrusy flavor and are essential in Mexican cuisine, particularly in green salsas and sauces.

name: Other solanacea
description: Various other fruiting vegetables from the Solanaceae family not specifically categorized elsewhere, including less common varieties related to tomatoes, peppers, and eggplants.

name: Bitter melon (balsam pear)
description: Bitter melon is a tropical vine-grown vegetable with a distinctive warty exterior and very bitter taste. Popular in Asian, Caribbean and Indian cuisines, it's valued for both culinary and medicinal properties.

name: Courgettes, zucchini, summer squash
description: These are varieties of tender squash harvested when immature. They have soft, edible skin and mild flavor, typically dark or light green (zucchini/courgette) or yellow (summer squash) in color.

name: Cucumbers
description: Cucumbers are long, cylindrical vegetables with high water content and crisp texture. They have a mild, refreshing flavor and are commonly eaten raw in salads and sandwiches or pickled.

name: Gherkins
description: Gherkins are small cucumbers specifically grown for pickling. They have bumpy skin and a crisp texture, typically preserved in vinegar, salt, and spices as a condiment or snack.

name: Mexican squash (choyote or christophine)
description: Chayote is a light green, pear-shaped squash with a single large seed and mild flavor. Its flesh is crisp when raw and softens when cooked, used in various Latin American and Asian cuisines.

name: Other cucurbits-edible peel
description: Various other members of the Cucurbitaceae family with edible peels not specifically categorized elsewhere, including specialty and regional varieties of squash and gourds.

name: Melons, cantaloupes
description: Cantaloupes and other melons are sweet, juicy fruits with netted or smooth rinds and orange, green, or white flesh. They have high water content and distinctive sweet aromas, typically eaten fresh.

name: Pumpkins & squashes (winter squash, marrows)
description: These are hard-skinned squashes with dense flesh, harvested when fully mature. They include varieties like butternut, acorn, and kabocha, with sweet, nutty flavors that intensify when cooked.

name: Watermelons
description: Watermelons are large fruits with green rinds and sweet, juicy red or yellow flesh containing numerous black seeds or seedless. They have extremely high water content and are valued for their refreshing sweetness.

name: Other cucurbits-inedible peel
description: Various other members of the Cucurbitaceae family with inedible peels not specifically categorized elsewhere, including specialty and regional varieties of squash, gourds, and melons.

name: Okra (bhindi, gumbo, ladies fingers)
description: Okra is a green, finger-shaped pod with tiny seeds and distinctive mucilaginous texture when cooked. It has a mild, grassy flavor and is popular in Southern American, Caribbean, Indian, and Middle Eastern cuisines.

name: Sweetcorn and baby corn
description: Sweetcorn consists of large ears with sweet kernels, while baby corn is harvested immature. Both have sweet flavor with varying levels of starchiness and are used in diverse culinary applications worldwide.

name: Broccoli, calabrese
description: Broccoli is a brassica vegetable with tight clusters of green florets on thick stalks. It has a grassy, slightly bitter flavor that sweetens when cooked and is highly nutritious with numerous culinary applications.

name: Cauliflower
description: Cauliflower features dense clusters of white florets (though purple, orange and green varieties exist) with a mild, slightly nutty flavor. It's versatile in cooking, used raw, roasted, steamed or as a low-carb substitute.

name: Chinese broccoli/kale, kai lan, gai lan, cai ro and choi sum
description: These are leafy Asian brassicas with thick stems and dark green leaves. They have slightly bitter, mustard-like flavors that mellow when cooked and are common in Chinese and Southeast Asian cuisines.

name: Brussels sprouts
description: Brussels sprouts are small, cabbage-like buds that grow on a tall stalk. They have a nutty, slightly bitter flavor that becomes sweeter when properly cooked, particularly when roasted or caramelized.

name: Other flowering brassicas
description: Various other brassica vegetables grown for their flowering parts not specifically categorized elsewhere, including specialty varieties and hybrids with unique characteristics and culinary applications.

name: Head cabbage
description: Head cabbage forms a dense, round head of tightly wrapped leaves. Varieties include green, red, and savoy, each with slightly different flavors ranging from mild to peppery, used both raw and cooked.

name: Other head brassicas
description: Various other brassica vegetables that form heads not specifically categorized elsewhere, including regional and specialty varieties with diverse characteristics and culinary applications.

name: Chinese cabbage and pak choi, bok choi
description: Asian brassicas including Napa cabbage (barrel-shaped with crinkled leaves) and bok choy (spoon-shaped stems with dark leaves). They have mild, sweet flavors and are staples in East Asian cuisines.

name: Kale (includes collards)
description: Kale and collard greens are leafy brassicas with robust, ruffled leaves. They have earthy, slightly bitter flavors that mellow when cooked and are highly nutritious, used in various global cuisines.

name: Other leafy brassicas
description: Various other leafy members of the brassica family not specifically categorized elsewhere, including mustard greens, turnip greens, and specialty varieties with diverse characteristics and uses.

name: Kohlrabi
description: Kohlrabi is a brassica vegetable with a swollen, bulb-like stem and radiating leaves. It has a crisp texture and mild, sweet flavor similar to broccoli stems or cabbage hearts, eaten both raw and cooked.

name: Cress
description: Cress is a small, fast-growing leaf vegetable with a distinctive peppery flavor. Garden cress and watercress are common varieties, often used in sandwiches, salads, and as a garnish.

name: Microgreens (other than cress)
description: Microgreens are young vegetable greens harvested just after sprouting. They have intense flavors and concentrated nutrients, used primarily as garnishes and in gourmet cuisine.

name: Lambs lettuce (corn salad)
description: Lamb's lettuce has small, dark green spoon-shaped leaves with a distinctive nutty flavor. Also known as corn salad or mâche, it's a delicate green often used in winter salads, particularly in European cuisine.

name: Land cress
description: Land cress is a leafy green with a peppery flavor similar to watercress but grows in soil rather than water. It's used in salads, sandwiches and as a garnish where its spicy notes add complexity.

name: Lettuce
description: Lettuce encompasses many varieties including iceberg, romaine, butterhead, and loose-leaf types. They have crisp textures and mild flavors ranging from sweet to slightly bitter, primarily used in salads and sandwiches.

name: Red mustard
description: Red mustard is a leafy vegetable with purple-red leaves and a pungent, peppery flavor. It's used in salad mixes, stir-fries, and as a garnish where its spicy notes and vibrant color add interest.

name: Ruccola (rocket, arugula)
description: Arugula has distinctive lobed leaves with a peppery, sometimes nutty flavor that becomes more intense as the leaves mature. Popular in Mediterranean cuisines, it's used in salads, on pizzas, and in pesto.

name: Leaves and stems of brassica
description: This category includes edible leaves and stems from the brassica family not categorized elsewhere, which may include shoots, sprouts, and young leaves from various cabbage-family plants.

name: Scarole (broad-leaf endive) & frisée
description: Escarole has broad, slightly curved leaves with mild flavor, while frisée has finely cut, curly leaves with more bitterness. Both are endive varieties used in salads and cooking, particularly in Mediterranean cuisines.

name: Other lettuce-like and salad vegetables
description: Various other leafy vegetables suitable for salads not specifically categorized elsewhere, including specialty greens, seasonal varieties, and regional salad components with diverse flavors and textures.

name: Spinach
description: Spinach consists of dark green, tender leaves with a mild, slightly sweet flavor that intensifies when cooked. It's highly nutritious and versatile, used both raw in salads and cooked in numerous dishes.

name: Beet leaves (chard)
description: Swiss chard features large, crinkled leaves with colorful stems ranging from white to yellow, red, and rainbow varieties. It has an earthy flavor similar to beets in the leaves and a mild sweetness in the stems.

name: Purslane
description: Purslane has succulent, paddle-shaped leaves and reddish stems with a slightly sour, salty flavor. It's used in salads, as a thickening agent in soups, and in various Mediterranean and Middle Eastern dishes.

name: Other spinach-like leaf vegetables
description: Various leafy greens with characteristics similar to spinach not specifically categorized elsewhere, including regional varieties, specialty greens, and leafy vegetables used in similar culinary applications.

name: Vine leaves
description: Vine leaves, typically from grape vines, are large and slightly bitter leaves used as wrappers for stuffed dishes. Most famously used in dolmas or dolmades in Mediterranean and Middle Eastern cuisines.

name: Watercress
description: Watercress has small, round leaves on thin stems with a distinctive peppery, slightly bitter flavor. It grows in running water and is used in salads, soups, sandwiches, and as a garnish.

name: Ong choi (fresh water spinach)
description: Water spinach has long, hollow stems and arrow-shaped leaves with a mild flavor similar to regular spinach. Popular in East and Southeast Asian cuisines, typically stir-fried with garlic and other seasonings.

name: Witloof (chicory) and forced radicchio
description: Belgian endive (witloof) has pale, tightly packed leaves with a slightly bitter flavor. Forced radicchio undergoes a process to create tight heads with distinctive coloration, both valued for their crisp texture.

name: Other leaf vegetables (not lettuce or spinach-like)
description: Various other leaf vegetables not fitting into specific lettuce or spinach categories, including specialty greens, regional varieties, and lesser-known leafy vegetables with diverse characteristics.

name: Basil
description: Basil is an aromatic herb with sweet, slightly peppery leaves. Common in Mediterranean and Asian cuisines, it's essential for Italian pesto and Thai dishes, available in several varieties including sweet, Thai, and purple.

name: Bay leaves (sweet bay, laurel)
description: Bay leaves are aromatic leaves from the bay laurel tree with a subtle, woody flavor. They're typically used whole in soups, stews, and braises to add depth of flavor and removed before serving.

name: Celery leaves (Chinese celery)
description: Celery leaves and Chinese celery have a more pronounced flavor than celery stalks. They're used as herbs rather than vegetables, adding aromatic depth to soups, stews, and stir-fries in various cuisines.

name: Centella (Asiatic pennywort, gotu kola)
description: Centella is an herb with round, fan-shaped leaves and a subtle bitter flavor. Popular in Southeast Asian cuisines for salads and drinks, it's also used in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.

name: Chervil
description: Chervil has delicate, frilly leaves with a mild flavor similar to parsley but with hints of anise. It's one of the fine herbs in French cuisine, commonly used in omelets, salads, and fish dishes.

name: Chives
description: Chives are slender, hollow green stems with a mild onion flavor. Often used as a garnish, they add subtle allium flavor and bright color to dishes like soups, potatoes, eggs, and soft cheeses.

name: Coriander leaves (cilantro)
description: Coriander leaves (cilantro) have a distinctive bright, citrusy flavor. Essential in Mexican, Indian, and Southeast Asian cuisines, they're used both as an ingredient and garnish in numerous dishes.

name: Curry leaves (Bergera/Murraya koenigii)
description: Curry leaves are aromatic leaves with a unique citrus-like flavor. Essential in South Indian cuisine, they're typically fried in oil at the beginning of cooking to release their distinctive aroma and flavor.

name: Dill leaves
description: Dill has feathery green leaves with a fresh, grassy flavor with notes of anise and lemon. Popular in Scandinavian, Eastern European, and Mediterranean cuisines for fish dishes, pickles, and yogurt-based sauces.

name: Lemongrass
description: Lemongrass is a tall, stalky herb with a citrusy, lemon-like flavor without the acidity. Essential in Southeast Asian cuisines, particularly Thai and Vietnamese, used in soups, curries, and stir-fries.

name: Marjoram
description: Marjoram has small, oval leaves with a mild, sweet flavor similar to oregano but gentler and with floral notes. Common in Mediterranean cuisines, particularly for meat dishes, stews, and vegetable preparations.

name: Mint
description: Mint comprises various aromatic herbs with cool, refreshing flavors. Varieties include spearmint and peppermint, used in beverages, desserts, Middle Eastern and Southeast Asian cuisines, and as a garnish.

name: Oregano
description: Oregano has small, oval leaves with a robust, aromatic flavor that's slightly bitter and pungent. Essential in Mediterranean cuisines, particularly Italian and Greek, commonly used in tomato sauces, pizza, and grilled meats.

name: Paan leaves (Betel)
description: Paan or betel leaves are heart-shaped with a slightly bitter taste. In South and Southeast Asian cultures, they're used as wraps for various fillings in a preparation called paan, often consumed after meals.

name: Parsley
description: Parsley has curly or flat leaves with a fresh, slightly peppery flavor. One of the most widely used herbs globally, it functions as both garnish and ingredient in numerous cuisines, particularly Mediterranean and Middle Eastern.

name: Perilla
description: Perilla (shiso) has broad leaves with serrated edges and a distinctive flavor combining mint, basil, and anise notes. Essential in East Asian cuisines, particularly Japanese and Korean, used in various dishes and as a wrap.

name: Rosemary
description: Rosemary has needle-like leaves with an intense aromatic, piney flavor. Common in Mediterranean cuisine, it pairs particularly well with roasted meats, potatoes, and bread, and can be used fresh or dried.

name: Sage
description: Sage has soft, gray-green leaves with a warm, aromatic flavor that's slightly bitter and astringent. Common in European cuisines, particularly with fatty meats, stuffings, and in Italian dishes like saltimbocca.

name: Tarragon
description: Tarragon has narrow, pointed leaves with a distinctive anise-like flavor. A key herb in French cuisine, it's used in béarnaise sauce, with chicken and fish dishes, and as one of the fines herbes blend.

name: Thyme
description: Thyme has tiny, aromatic leaves with an earthy, slightly floral flavor. Available in several varieties including common and lemon thyme, it's widely used in European cuisines for meats, stews, and soups.

name: Other herbs - fresh
description: Various other fresh culinary herbs not specifically categorized elsewhere, including regional specialties, less common varieties, and seasonal fresh herbs used in diverse global cuisines.

name: Other herbs - dried
description: Various dried herbs not specifically categorized elsewhere, including single herbs, herb mixes, and regional spice blends containing primarily dried herbs used in diverse culinary traditions.

name: Beans with pods (French: P. vulgaris type), haricots verts
description: French beans are long, slender green beans with tender pods. They're typically eaten whole (pod and seeds) when young and tender, common in many cuisines for side dishes, salads, and stir-fries.

name: Beans with pods (yard long, asparagus, valor, papri, ethnic)
description: Various specialty beans with edible pods, including yard-long beans, winged beans, and other varieties common in Asian and ethnic cuisines. They vary in length, texture, and flavor profiles.

name: Beans without pods (broad etc.)
description: Beans where only the seeds are eaten, not the pods, such as fava (broad) beans. They have a buttery texture and nutty flavor when cooked, used in Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, and Chinese cuisines.

name: Peas with pods (snap, snow, mange tout)
description: Varieties of peas where the entire pod is edible, including snow peas (flat pods) and sugar snap peas (plump pods). They have a sweet, crisp texture and are commonly used in stir-fries and salads.

name: Peas without pods
description: Standard green peas where only the round seeds are eaten, not the pods. They have a sweet flavor and can be consumed fresh, frozen, or dried, used in numerous dishes across global cuisines.

name: Other legume vegetables
description: Various other fresh legume vegetables not specifically categorized elsewhere, including lesser-known regional varieties and specialty legumes consumed in their immature state.

name: Asparagus
description: Asparagus consists of young shoots with distinctive tips, available in green, white, or purple varieties. It has a grassy, earthy flavor and tender texture when properly cooked, often served as a side dish or in salads.

name: Cardoons
description: Cardoons are related to artichokes but grown for their edible stalks rather than flower buds. They have a bitter, artichoke-like flavor and are traditional in Mediterranean cuisine, typically braised or added to stews.

name: Celery
description: Celery has crisp, watery stalks with a mild, slightly bitter flavor. It's used as an aromatic base in many cuisines, eaten raw as a snack, and adds texture and subtle flavor to soups, stews, and salads.

name: Fennel
description: Fennel has a bulbous base with feathery fronds and a distinctive anise-like flavor. The bulb can be eaten raw or cooked, popular in Mediterranean cuisines, while fronds are used as herbs in various dishes.

name: Globe artichokes
description: Globe artichokes are the immature flower buds of a thistle plant. They have a tender heart and edible leaf bases with a subtle, nutty flavor. Popular in Mediterranean cuisines, typically steamed or braised.

name: Leeks
description: Leeks are allium vegetables with long white stems and dark green leaves. They have a mild, sweet onion-like flavor and are commonly used in soups, particularly vichyssoise, stews, and other European dishes.

name: Rhubarb
description: Rhubarb has long, pink to red stalks with a tart flavor. The stalks are edible (leaves are toxic) and typically cooked with sugar in desserts, jams, and compotes, popular in European and North American cuisines.

name: Bamboo shoots
description: Bamboo shoots are young, edible shoots of bamboo plants. They have a crisp texture and mild flavor, requiring proper cooking to remove bitterness. Essential in many East and Southeast Asian cuisines.

name: Palm hearts
description: Palm hearts are harvested from the inner core of certain palm trees. They have a tender texture and subtle, slightly nutty flavor, commonly used in salads and other dishes in tropical American and Caribbean cuisines.

name: Nopales (cactus pads)
description: Nopales are the flat pads of prickly pear cacti (spines removed). They have a tart, slightly slimy texture similar to okra when cooked, widely used in Mexican cuisine in various dishes, salads, and stews.

name: Other stem vegetables
description: Various other vegetables grown primarily for their edible stems not specifically categorized elsewhere, including regional specialties and less common stem vegetables with diverse culinary applications.

name: Cultivated mushrooms and fungi
description: Mushrooms grown commercially including varieties like button, cremini, portobello, shiitake, oyster, and enoki. They have varying flavors and textures, from mild to rich and meaty, used in diverse cuisines worldwide.

name: Wild mushrooms and fungi
description: Mushrooms foraged from the wild including varieties like chanterelles, morels, porcini, and truffles. They typically have more intense flavors than cultivated varieties and are prized in gourmet cooking.

name: Yeast and yeast products
description: Yeasts are single-celled fungi used in food production, including baker's yeast for bread, brewer's yeast for beer, and nutritional yeast as a food supplement. They contribute to fermentation and flavor development.

name: Beans (dry)
description: Dried beans are legume seeds that have been harvested when mature and dried. They include varieties like kidney, pinto, black, navy, and cannellini beans, used in diverse cuisines globally after soaking and cooking.

name: Chickpeas (dry)
description: Dried chickpeas are round, beige legume seeds with a nutty flavor and firm texture after cooking. Essential in Middle Eastern, Indian, and Mediterranean cuisines for dishes like hummus, falafel, and various stews.

name: Lentils (dry)
description: Dried lentils are small, lens-shaped legume seeds available in various colors including green, brown, red, and black. They cook relatively quickly and are staples in cuisines across South Asia, the Middle East, and Europe.

name: Lupins (dry)
description: Dried lupins are legume seeds that must be properly prepared to remove bitter alkaloids before consumption. They're popular as snacks in Mediterranean and Latin American countries and increasingly used in plant-based proteins.

name: Peas (dry)
description: Dried peas are mature legume seeds that have been dried, including yellow and green split peas and whole dried peas. They're used in soups, stews, and purees across various cuisines, particularly Northern European.

name: Other pulses (dry)
description: Various other dried legume seeds not specifically categorized elsewhere, including pigeon peas, black-eyed peas, fava beans, and regional varieties used in diverse culinary traditions worldwide.

name: Peanuts and peanut products (inc. peanut butter)
description: Peanuts are legumes with a distinctive nutty flavor, consumed whole, ground into butter, or processed into oil. Despite being classified botanically as legumes, they're commonly used like tree nuts in culinary applications.

name: Soybeans (dry)
description: Dried soybeans are protein-rich legume seeds with high oil content. They're used to make numerous products including tofu, tempeh, miso, soy sauce, and soy milk, and are central to many Asian cuisines.

name: Soybean products (tofu, tempeh, etc)
description: Products made from soybeans including tofu (soybean curd with varying textures), tempeh (fermented soybean cake), miso (fermented soybean paste), and other traditional and modern soy-based foods.

name: Rapeseed/canola seed
description: Seeds from rapeseed/canola plants primarily grown for their oil content. The seeds themselves are rarely consumed directly but are pressed to produce canola oil, widely used in cooking for its neutral flavor.

name: Sunflower seeds
description: Seeds from sunflower plants with a mild, nutty flavor. They're consumed directly as snacks (shelled or unshelled), used in baking, or pressed to extract sunflower oil, popular in both culinary and commercial food applications.

name: Sesame seeds
description: Small seeds with a nutty, slightly sweet flavor that intensifies when toasted. Used in cuisines worldwide as toppings for breads and pastries, in spice blends, and processed into tahini paste or pressed for oil.

name: Flaxseed/linseed
description: Small, brown or golden seeds with a nutty flavor and high omega-3 fatty acid content. Used in baking, as a nutritional supplement, and pressed for linseed oil, which has both culinary and industrial applications.

name: Poppy seeds
description: Tiny blue-black seeds with a mild, nutty flavor. Widely used in baking for breads, pastries, and desserts across European, Middle Eastern, and Indian cuisines, and processed into paste for fillings.

name: Hemp seeds
description: Seeds from the hemp plant with a mild, nutty flavor similar to pine nuts. Rich in protein and healthy fats, they're consumed whole, hulled (hemp hearts), as hemp milk, or pressed for oil.

name: Other oilseeds
description: Various other seeds grown primarily for oil extraction not specifically categorized elsewhere, including mustard seeds, cottonseed, safflower seeds, and regional varieties with diverse culinary and industrial applications.

name: Wheat and products
description: Wheat grains and derived products including flour, semolina, bulgur, and wheat berries. The world's most widely consumed grain, it's the primary ingredient in breads, pasta, noodles, and numerous baked goods.

name: Rice and products
description: Rice in various forms including white, brown, wild, and specialty varieties, plus products like rice flour and rice noodles. A dietary staple for over half the world's population, particularly in Asian cuisines.

name: Corn (maize) and products
description: Corn (maize) kernels and derived products including cornmeal, corn flour, grits, and masa. A staple grain in the Americas, Africa, and parts of Asia, used in diverse preparations from tortillas to porridge.

name: Barley and products
description: Barley grains and products including pearl barley, barley flakes, and barley flour. One of the earliest cultivated grains, used in soups, stews, breads, and as the primary grain for beer production.

name: Oats and products
description: Oat grains and products including rolled oats, steel-cut oats, oat flour, and oatmeal. Known for their high fiber content and hearty flavor, commonly consumed as breakfast porridge and in baked goods.

name: Rye and products
description: Rye grains and products including rye flour, rye berries, and cracked rye. Has a distinctive strong flavor, commonly used in dense, dark breads, particularly in Northern and Eastern European cuisines.

name: Millet and products
description: Small, round grains from various grass species and their derived products. Gluten-free with a mild flavor, millet is a staple in parts of Africa and Asia, used in porridges, flatbreads, and fermented beverages.

name: Sorghum and products
description: Sorghum grains and derived products including flour and syrup. A drought-resistant grain with a mild, sweet flavor, important in African, Asian, and Central American cuisines for porridges, flatbreads, and beverages.

name: Quinoa
description: Small, round pseudo-cereal seeds with a fluffy texture and nutty flavor when cooked. Originally from South America, quinoa is notable for its complete protein content and has become popular globally in salads and as a grain alternative.

name: Amaranth
description: Tiny pseudo-cereal seeds with a nutty flavor and slightly crunchy texture when cooked. Used in traditional Mexican, Peruvian, and Indian cuisines for porridges, breads, and popped as a snack.

name: Buckwheat
description: Triangle-shaped pseudo-cereal seeds with an earthy, nutty flavor. Despite its name, it's not related to wheat and is gluten-free, commonly used in Eastern European, Russian, and Japanese cuisines for groats, noodles, and pancakes.

name: Other cereal grains and products
description: Various other grains and grain-like seeds not specifically categorized elsewhere, including teff, fonio, kamut, spelt, and regional grain varieties with diverse culinary applications worldwide.

name: Whitefish (cod, haddock, pollock, etc)
description: Lean fish with mild flavor and white, flaky flesh when cooked. This category includes cod, haddock, pollock, and similar species commonly used in fish and chips, chowders, and various baked and fried preparations.

name: Oily fish (salmon, mackerel, herring, etc)
description: Fish with higher fat content and stronger flavors, including salmon, mackerel, herring, sardines, and anchovies. Rich in omega-3 fatty acids, they're consumed fresh, smoked, canned, and in various traditional preparations.

name: Flatfish (plaice, sole, flounder, etc)
description: Fish with a distinctive flat body shape and eyes on one side. They have delicate, mild-flavored white flesh, typically prepared by pan-frying, grilling, or baking with minimal seasonings to preserve their subtle flavor.

name: Tuna and similar species
description: Large pelagic fish including various tuna species, bonito, and skipjack. They have firm, meaty flesh ranging from light to dark red, consumed fresh as steaks or sashimi, and widely available canned in oil or water.

name: Freshwater fish
description: Fish species that live in freshwater environments including trout, tilapia, carp, catfish, and perch. They vary widely in flavor and texture, prepared according to regional cuisines where they're traditionally caught.

name: Crustaceans (shrimp, crab, lobster)
description: Aquatic arthropods with hard shells including shrimp, prawns, crab, lobster, and crayfish. They have sweet, distinctive flavors and are considered delicacies in many cuisines, prepared by boiling, steaming, grilling, or in stews.

name: Mollusks (oysters, mussels, clams, scallops)
description: Soft-bodied invertebrates typically with shells, including bivalves (oysters, mussels, clams, scallops) and cephalopods (squid, octopus). They range from delicate to robust flavors and are prepared in countless ways across global cuisines.

name: Fish products (fish paste, fish sauce)
description: Fermented or processed fish products used as condiments and flavor enhancers. Includes fish sauce, fish paste, anchovy paste, and similar products that are fundamental ingredients in many Southeast Asian and Mediterranean cuisines.

name: Other fish and seafood
description: Various other aquatic foods not specifically categorized elsewhere, including less common fish species, sea urchins, sea cucumbers, and regional seafood specialties with diverse culinary applications worldwide.

name: Beef and veal
description: Meat from cattle, including various cuts from different parts of the animal. Beef has a rich flavor that varies by cut, with applications ranging from steaks and roasts to ground meat for burgers and stews.

name: Pork
description: Meat from domestic pigs in various cuts. It has a mild flavor and versatile culinary applications including chops, roasts, ground meat, and is the primary meat for many cured products like bacon and ham.

name: Lamb and mutton
description: Meat from sheep, with lamb from younger animals and mutton from mature ones. It has a distinctive flavor, stronger in mutton than lamb, and is central to Middle Eastern, North African, and certain European cuisines.

name: Poultry (chicken, turkey, duck)
description: Meat from domesticated birds including chicken, turkey, duck, and goose. Ranges from the mild flavor of chicken to the richer taste of duck, with applications in virtually every global cuisine.

name: Game meats
description: Meat from wild or farm-raised non-domesticated animals including venison, rabbit, wild boar, and game birds. They typically have stronger, more distinctive flavors than conventional meats and feature in regional cuisines worldwide.

name: Processed meat products (sausages, salami)
description: Meat products that have been transformed through curing, smoking, fermentation, or other processes. Includes sausages, salami, ham, bacon, and regional specialties from diverse culinary traditions.

name: Offal and organ meats
description: Edible organs and tissues including liver, kidney, heart, brain, sweetbreads, and tripe. They vary widely in flavor and texture and are important components of traditional cuisines focused on whole-animal consumption.

name: Other meat products
description: Various other meat products not specifically categorized elsewhere, including specialty meats, processed products, and regional meat preparations with diverse culinary applications worldwide.

name: Milk (fresh)
description: Fresh liquid milk from cows, goats, sheep, or other mammals. Used as a beverage, in cooking, and as a base for many other dairy products, with variations in fat content from whole to skim.

name: Milk powders
description: Dehydrated milk products created by removing water from liquid milk. They have a long shelf life and are used in baking, confectionery, as nutritional supplements, and for reconstituting into liquid milk where fresh is unavailable.

name: Cheese
description: Fermented milk products in hundreds of varieties, ranging from soft to hard and mild to strong. Created through various aging and processing methods, cheese is used in countless dishes across global cuisines.

name: Butter and ghee
description: Concentrated milk fat products: butter is made by churning cream while ghee is clarified butter with milk solids removed. Both have rich flavors and are used in cooking, baking, and as spreads.

name: Cream and clotted cream
description: High-fat components of milk in various consistencies from light pouring cream to thick clotted cream. Used in cooking, desserts, as coffee additions, and with scones and other baked goods.

name: Yogurt and fermented milk products
description: Milk products fermented with beneficial bacteria, including yogurt, kefir, and similar cultured dairy items. They have tangy flavors, various textures, and are consumed directly or used in numerous sweet and savory dishes.

name: Ice cream and frozen dairy desserts
description: Frozen sweet desserts made from dairy products, typically containing cream, milk, sugar, and flavorings. Includes traditional ice cream, gelato, frozen yogurt, and other frozen milk-based treats.

name: Other dairy products
description: Various other milk-derived products not specifically categorized elsewhere, including specialty dairy items, regional preparations, and traditional dairy foods from diverse culinary traditions.

name: Eggs
description: Whole eggs in shell, primarily from chickens but also from ducks, quail, geese, and other birds. Versatile ingredients used in countless culinary applications from simple preparations to complex baking and cooking.

name: Egg products (liquid, powder)
description: Processed egg components including liquid egg whites or yolks, whole egg mixtures, and powdered egg products. Used in commercial food production, baking, and for convenience in food service and home cooking.

name: Sugar and sweeteners
description: Crystalline sucrose and other sweetening agents from various sources including cane, beet, corn, and artificial sweeteners. Used primarily to add sweetness to foods and beverages and for preservation in certain products.

name: Honey
description: Natural sweet substance produced by bees from flower nectar. Varies in color, flavor, and consistency depending on the floral source, used as a sweetener, in baking, as a spread, and for its potential health benefits.

name: Maple and other natural syrups
description: Concentrated sweet liquids derived from plant sources, including maple syrup from tree sap and various fruit or plant syrups. Used as sweeteners, toppings, and flavoring agents in diverse culinary applications.

name: Chocolate and cocoa products
description: Products derived from cacao beans including chocolate bars, cocoa powder, and confectionery items. Range from unsweetened bitter cocoa to sweet milk chocolate, used in countless desserts, beverages, and some savory dishes.

name: Jams, jellies and preserves
description: Sweet spreads made from fruits preserved with sugar. Jams contain fruit pieces, jellies are clear and smooth, and preserves have larger fruit chunks, all commonly used on breads, in pastries, and as condiments.

name: Other sugar products and sweets
description: Various other sweet products not specifically categorized elsewhere, including confectionery items, specialty sugars, traditional sweets, and regional sweet preparations from diverse culinary traditions.

name: Vegetable oils and fats
description: Oils extracted from plants including olive, sunflower, canola, coconut, and palm oils. They have different flavor profiles, smoke points, and nutritional properties, used for cooking, salad dressings, and food manufacturing.

name: Animal fats
description: Fats derived from animals including lard (pork), tallow (beef), duck fat, and schmaltz (chicken). They have distinctive flavors and high smoke points, traditionally used in various cuisines for cooking, baking, and preservation.

name: Margarine and similar spreads
description: Plant-based butter alternatives made from vegetable oils that have been emulsified and solidified. Used as spreads, in baking, and cooking as an alternative to butter, with varying fat contents and compositions.

name: Tomato sauces and pastes
description: Concentrated tomato products ranging from thick pastes to ready-to-use sauces. Used as bases for other sauces, in soups, stews, and numerous dishes across Mediterranean, American, and global cuisines.

name: Mayonnaise and dressings
description: Emulsified oil-based condiments including mayonnaise and various salad dressings. Used as spreads, dips, and flavor enhancers in sandwiches, salads, and as bases for other sauces and dressings.

name: Ketchup and similar sauces
description: Condiments based on tomatoes or other vegetables with vinegar, sugar, and spices. Includes ketchup, brown sauce, and similar preparations used as table condiments and cooking ingredients.

name: Mustard and prepared mustard
description: Condiments made from ground mustard seeds mixed with liquids and other seasonings. Ranges from mild yellow American mustard to spicy Dijon and whole-grain varieties, used in sandwiches, dressings, and numerous culinary applications.

name: Soy sauce and similar products
description: Fermented condiments made from soybeans, wheat, salt, and water. Includes traditional soy sauce, tamari, and similar umami-rich liquid seasonings essential in Asian cuisines and increasingly used worldwide.

name: Vinegars
description: Acidic liquids produced through fermentation of various base ingredients including wine, apple cider, rice, and malt. Used in cooking, pickling, dressings, and as flavor enhancers across global cuisines.

name: Stock cubes, powders, liquid stocks
description: Concentrated flavor bases in solid or liquid form, typically made from meat, vegetables, or combinations. Used to add depth of flavor to soups, stews, sauces, and various cooked dishes.

name: Prepared soups and broths
description: Ready-to-eat or ready-to-heat liquid food preparations based on stock or broth with various ingredients. Available canned, dried, or frozen, ranging from clear consommés to thick, chunky vegetable or meat soups.

name: Prepared meals and convenience foods
description: Ready-to-eat or minimally prepared food products designed for convenience. Includes frozen meals, packet mixes, shelf-stable preparations, and other foods requiring minimal preparation before consumption.

name: Other processed foods and sauces
description: Various other prepared food products and condiments not specifically categorized elsewhere, including specialty sauces, regional preparations, and manufactured food products from diverse culinary traditions.

name: Tea leaves and bags
description: Processed leaves of the tea plant (Camellia sinensis) in loose or bagged form. Available in numerous varieties including black, green, white, and oolong, used to prepare hot or cold beverages consumed worldwide.

name: Coffee beans and ground
description: Roasted seeds of the coffee plant in whole bean or ground form. Varies widely in flavor based on origin, processing, and roasting level, primarily used to prepare hot and cold coffee beverages.

name: Herbal infusions
description: Dried herbs, flowers, fruits, and spices used to prepare hot beverages that aren't derived from the tea plant. Includes chamomile, mint, rooibos, and countless other botanical preparations consumed for flavor and reputed health benefits.

name: Fruit and vegetable juices
description: Extracted liquid from fruits and vegetables, consumed as beverages. Available fresh, pasteurized, or from concentrate in countless varieties and combinations, valued for flavor and nutritional content.

name: Soft drinks and sodas
description: Carbonated beverages typically containing water, sweeteners, and flavorings. Includes colas, lemonades, fruit-flavored sodas, and other non-alcoholic carbonated drinks consumed globally.

name: Alcoholic beverages
description: Drinks containing ethanol produced through fermentation and distillation. Includes beer, wine, spirits, and other alcoholic products that vary widely in alcohol content, flavor, and cultural significance worldwide.

name: Other beverages
description: Various other drinks not specifically categorized elsewhere, including energy drinks, sports beverages, plant-based milks, flavored waters, and specialty or regional beverages from diverse culinary traditions.

name: Salt and salt products
description: Sodium chloride in various forms including table salt, sea salt, and specialty salts. Essential for flavor enhancement in cooking and food preservation, available in different textures, colors, and mineral contents.

name: Black and white pepper
description: Dried berries of the Piper nigrum plant, with black pepper being the dried unripe fruit and white pepper the ripe seed with outer layer removed. One of the world's most common spices, used whole or ground for heat and flavor.

name: Chili powder and flakes
description: Dried, ground chili peppers in various forms from fine powder to flakes. Adds heat and flavor to dishes, with varieties ranging from mild to extremely spicy, used in countless cuisines worldwide.

name: Spice mixes and blends
description: Combinations of multiple ground spices mixed in specific proportions. Includes curry powders, garam masala, five-spice powder, herbes de Provence, and numerous regional and traditional blends from global cuisines.

name: Individual spices (not specified elsewhere)
description: Various individual dried spices not specifically categorized elsewhere, including cinnamon, cumin, coriander, turmeric, cardamom, cloves, nutmeg, and many others used in diverse culinary traditions worldwide.

name: Pickles and fermented vegetables
description: Vegetables preserved through fermentation or pickling in vinegar, brine, or other solutions. Includes cucumber pickles, sauerkraut, kimchi, and various other preserved vegetables from culinary traditions worldwide.

name: Other condiments
description: Various other flavor-enhancing preparations not specifically categorized elsewhere, including relishes, chutneys, and specialty or regional condiments from diverse culinary traditions worldwide.

name: Breads and rolls
description: Baked products made primarily from flour, water, and leavening agents. Includes loaves, baguettes, rolls, flatbreads, and countless regional variations that form dietary staples across many cultures worldwide.

name: Pastries and sweet baked goods
description: Sweet flour-based baked items including croissants, danishes, doughnuts, and similar products. Often enriched with butter, sugar, eggs, and filled or topped with sweet ingredients like fruits, cream, or chocolate.

name: Cakes and pies
description: Dessert baked goods including layer cakes, sheet cakes, fruit pies, cream pies, and tarts. Sweet confections that serve as celebratory foods and desserts in cuisines worldwide with countless varieties and flavors.

name: Cookies and biscuits
description: Small, flat baked goods including sweet cookies and savory crackers. They range from crisp to chewy in texture and come in countless flavor varieties, shapes, and sizes for snacking and dessert purposes.

name: Savory pastries and pies
description: Baked goods with non-sweet fillings including meat pies, quiches, empanadas, and similar items. Found in many world cuisines, they typically feature pastry crusts with savory fillings of meat, vegetables, or cheese.

name: Other baked products
description: Various other baked foods not specifically categorized elsewhere, including specialty items, regional specialties, and traditional baked goods from diverse culinary traditions worldwide.

name: Mixed salad leaves
description: Pre-washed and mixed leafy greens ready for salad preparation. Typically includes various lettuce varieties, sometimes with other greens like arugula or spinach, packaged for convenient salad preparation.

name: Prepared vegetable salads
description: Ready-to-eat salads made with vegetables, often with dressings or other ingredients. Includes coleslaw, potato salad, carrot salads, and various other vegetable-based salads prepared for immediate consumption.

name: Prepared salads with meat/fish
description: Ready-to-eat salads containing animal proteins along with vegetables. Includes chicken salad, tuna salad, seafood salad, and other protein-based salad preparations typically used as sandwich fillings or stand-alone dishes.

name: Pre-cut vegetables
description: Fresh vegetables that have been washed and cut for convenience. Includes ready-to-cook stir-fry mixes, vegetable medleys, spiralized vegetables, and individual cleaned and pre-cut vegetables for quicker meal preparation.

name: Edible algae (seaweed/kelp)
description: Marine plants and algae consumed as food, including nori, kombu, wakame, and dulse. Used in East Asian cuisines for wrapping sushi, flavoring broths, in salads, and increasingly in global fusion cooking.

name: Edible flowers
description: Flowers that can be consumed safely and are used in culinary applications. Includes varieties like nasturtiums, pansies, and squash blossoms, used primarily as garnishes or in salads for their visual appeal and subtle flavors.

name: Other foods of plant origin
description: Various other edible plant products not specifically categorized elsewhere, including specialty items, foraged plants, and regional plant foods with diverse culinary applications worldwide.

name: Oats
description: Oats are cereal grains with a mild, slightly nutty flavor. They're typically processed as rolled oats, steel-cut oats, or oat flour, and are valued for their high fiber content. Commonly used in breakfast foods, baking, and increasingly in plant-based milks.

name: Triticale
description: Triticale is a hybrid grain created by crossing wheat and rye. It combines the yield of wheat with the hardiness of rye and has a slightly sweet, nutty flavor. Used in breads, cereals, and as animal feed, particularly in organic farming systems.

name: Maize (yellow corn)
description: Yellow corn is a cereal grain with sweet, starchy kernels. It's a dietary staple in many parts of the world, used in countless forms including cornmeal, cornbread, tortillas, polenta, and as a side dish when served fresh.

name: Buckwheat
description: Buckwheat is a pseudo-cereal (not a true grain) with triangular seeds and a robust, earthy flavor. Despite its name, it's not related to wheat and is gluten-free, commonly used for pancakes, noodles (soba), groats (kasha), and in Eastern European cuisine.

name: Millet
description: Millet refers to a group of small-seeded grasses cultivated as cereal crops. They have a mild, slightly sweet flavor and are naturally gluten-free. Important staples in parts of Africa and Asia, used for porridges, breads, and fermented beverages.

name: Rice
description: Rice is one of the world's most important staple foods, with thousands of varieties grouped into categories like long-grain, short-grain, and medium-grain. Available in white (milled) or brown (whole grain) forms, it's central to cuisines across Asia and beyond.

name: Quinoa
description: Quinoa is a pseudo-cereal with small, round seeds and a fluffy texture when cooked. It has a mild, slightly nutty flavor and is notable for being a complete protein. Originally from South America, it's now popular worldwide as a nutritious grain alternative.

name: Other cereals
description: Various other cereal grains and pseudo-cereals not specifically categorized elsewhere, including ancient grains like einkorn, emmer, spelt, kamut, teff, and amaranth, as well as regional cereal varieties from diverse agricultural traditions.

name: Cassia seeds
description: Cassia seeds are small, dark brown seeds from the Cassia plant with a mild, sweet flavor. They're used in traditional Chinese medicine and some Asian cuisines for their aromatic properties and purported digestive benefits.

name: Chia seeds
description: Chia seeds are small, oval-shaped seeds that can be black, white, or brown. They absorb liquid to form a gel-like consistency and have a mild, nutty flavor. Rich in omega-3 fatty acids and fiber, they're used in puddings, smoothies, and as a nutritional supplement.

name: Grapefruit seeds (& extract - GSE)
description: Grapefruit seeds and their extract (GSE) come from the citrus fruit. While the seeds themselves are bitter and not typically consumed directly, the extract is used as a natural preservative and in alternative medicine for its purported antimicrobial properties.

name: Lotus seeds
description: Lotus seeds are white or cream-colored oval seeds from the sacred lotus plant. They have a mild, sweet flavor and are used in East Asian cuisines, particularly in desserts like lotus seed paste, soups, and mooncakes, and are also used in traditional medicine.

name: Melon (egusi) seeds
description: Egusi seeds come from certain varieties of melons and are a staple in West African cuisine. They have a high oil content and nutty flavor, commonly ground into paste for soups and stews where they act as thickeners and add rich flavor and protein.

name: Pumpkin seeds
