description: Pumpkin seeds are flat, green seeds from pumpkins and other squashes. They have a chewy texture and nutty flavor, especially when roasted. Rich in nutrients including magnesium and zinc, they're consumed as snacks, in baking, and as toppings for various dishes.

name: Other seeds - not listed
description: Various other edible seeds not specifically categorized elsewhere, including watermelon seeds, apple seeds (consumed in limited quantities), papaya seeds, and regional or specialty seed varieties with diverse culinary and traditional uses.

name: Other seeds - sprouted
description: Seeds that have been germinated to produce sprouts excluding those specifically categorized elsewhere. Sprouting often increases nutritional value and changes flavor profiles, with these sprouts used in salads, sandwiches, and various dishes.

name: Alfalfa sprouts
description: Alfalfa sprouts are germinated alfalfa seeds with delicate, crisp texture and mild, fresh flavor. They're commonly used in sandwiches, salads, and as garnishes, providing a nutritious addition with minimal calories and a light crunch.

name: Bean sprouts (mung beans)
description: Mung bean sprouts are germinated mung beans with crisp, juicy stems and small yellow leaves. They have a mild, fresh flavor and are staples in many Asian cuisines, particularly in stir-fries, soups, spring rolls, and as garnishes for noodle dishes.

name: Other sprouted seeds and mixed sprouts
description: Various other sprouted seeds and seed mixtures not categorized elsewhere, including broccoli sprouts, radish sprouts, sunflower sprouts, and commercial mixes combining multiple sprouted seed varieties for nutritional diversity and flavor.

name: Sugar beet
description: Sugar beets are root vegetables with high sucrose content, grown specifically for sugar production. They have a white, conical root and are processed to extract granulated sugar that's chemically identical to cane sugar, providing approximately 20% of the world's sugar.

name: Sugar cane
description: Sugarcane is a tall grass with jointed, fibrous stalks rich in sucrose. It's the primary source of table sugar globally, and is also used to produce molasses, rum, and ethanol. The stalks can be chewed directly for their sweet juice in some cultures.

name: Chicory roots (for inulin production)
description: Chicory roots contain inulin, a type of soluble fiber and natural sweetener. They're commonly roasted and ground as a coffee substitute or additive, and the extracted inulin is used as a prebiotic fiber supplement and in food manufacturing as a fat or sugar replacer.

name: Other sugar plants
description: Various other plants cultivated primarily for their sugar content not categorized elsewhere, including stevia, monk fruit, sweet sorghum, and regional sugar-producing plants with diverse applications in traditional and commercial food production.

name: Bran (all cereals)
description: Bran is the outer layer of cereal grains like wheat, rice, oats, and corn that's removed during refining. Rich in fiber, minerals, and some proteins, it's used in breakfast cereals, baked goods, and as a dietary supplement to increase fiber intake.

name: Germ (all cereals)
description: Cereal germ is the reproductive part of the grain, rich in essential fatty acids, vitamins, and minerals. Often removed during processing to extend shelf life, it can be consumed separately as a nutritional supplement or added to foods for nutritional enrichment.

name: Gluten (all cereals)
description: Gluten is a protein complex found primarily in wheat, barley, and rye. Extracted and used as a protein supplement, meat substitute, binding agent, and texture enhancer in food manufacturing, particularly in plant-based and vegetarian products.

name: Malt (all cereals)
description: Malt is germinated cereal grain (usually barley) that has been dried in a process known as malting. It develops enzymes that convert starches to sugars, essential in brewing, distilling, and making malted food products like malted milk and breakfast cereals.

name: Flour (all cereals except maize)
description: Ground cereal grains including wheat, rice, barley, and others (excluding corn). Available in various forms from whole grain to refined, flour is a fundamental ingredient in baking, cooking, and food manufacturing worldwide.

name: Other processed cereals (rusk, meal etc. excluding breading mixes)
description: Various processed cereal products not categorized elsewhere, including rusks (twice-baked bread), meals (coarse flours), and similar products. Used in cooking, baking, and as ingredients in other food preparations.

name: Semolina, couscous, farina
description: Milled wheat products with varying granule sizes. Semolina is coarse, used in pasta and puddings; couscous consists of tiny steamed granules common in North African cuisine; farina is finely ground for hot cereals and puddings.

name: Breads
description: Baked products made from flour dough, typically leavened with yeast or other raising agents. Available in countless varieties worldwide from soft sandwich loaves to crusty artisan breads, forming dietary staples in many cultures.

name: Pastries, biscuits, cakes etc.
description: Sweet or savory baked goods made with flour and typically containing fat. This diverse category includes flaky pastries, cookies/biscuits, cakes, pies, and similar items with varying ingredients, textures, and cultural origins.

name: Cereal snacks (other than maize-based)
description: Ready-to-eat snack foods made from wheat, rice, oats, and other non-corn cereals. Includes crackers, rice cakes, wheat-based chips, and similar products designed for convenient consumption between meals.

name: Breakfast cereals (other than maize-based)
description: Ready-to-eat or quick-cooking morning meal products made from wheat, rice, oats, or other non-corn grains. Includes flaked, puffed, and extruded cereals, muesli, granola, and porridge oats consumed with milk or yogurt.

name: Cereal snacks (maize-based)
description: Ready-to-eat snack foods made primarily from corn (maize). Includes tortilla chips, corn chips, cheese puffs, and similar extruded or baked corn-based products popular as convenient between-meal foods.

name: Breakfast cereals (maize-based)
description: Ready-to-eat morning meal products made primarily from corn (maize). Includes corn flakes, frosted corn cereals, puffed corn products, and similar items typically consumed with milk or yogurt as breakfast foods.

name: Pasta and noodles
description: Unleavened dough products shaped into various forms. Includes Italian pasta (spaghetti, macaroni), Asian noodles (ramen, udon, rice noodles), and similar products from various cultures, used as the base for numerous dishes worldwide.

name: Other processed starch foods
description: Various starch-based food products not categorized elsewhere. Includes dumplings, gnocchi, certain desserts, and regional specialties based on processed starches from various sources, with diverse culinary applications.

name: Polenta & maize flour/meal & cornmeal
description: Processed corn (maize) products including ground cornmeal and polenta, a boiled cornmeal dish that can be served soft or allowed to set and then sliced. Traditional in Italian, Latin American, and Southern US cuisines.

name: Other non-cereal flours (chia, chestnut, pumpkin etc)
description: Ground flours made from non-grain sources including seeds, nuts, and starchy vegetables. These alternative flours are often used in gluten-free baking, specialty dishes, and traditional recipes from various cultures.

name: Potato starch
description: Fine white powder extracted from potatoes, used as a thickening agent in cooking and baking. It creates a clear gel when heated and is particularly valued in gluten-free cooking, Eastern European cuisines, and Asian dishes.

name: Sago
description: Starch extracted from the pith of sago palm stems, processed into small pearl-like granules. Popular in Southeast Asian and Pacific Island cuisines for puddings, desserts, and as a thickener in both sweet and savory dishes.

name: Tapioca
description: Starch extracted from cassava root, processed into flakes, pearls, or powder. Used in puddings, bubble tea, as a thickening agent in cooking, and in various traditional dishes across South American, African, and Asian cuisines.

name: Other/unspecified starches
description: Various other purified starch products not specifically categorized elsewhere. Includes arrowroot, water chestnut starch, and other specialty or regional starch products used as thickeners and in traditional preparations worldwide.

name: Baby food
group_name: Foods for Infants and Young Children
description: Specially prepared foods for babies typically between 4-12 months old. Includes purees, mashes, and soft foods in various stages of consistency, designed to meet nutritional needs while transitioning from milk to solid foods.

name: Infant food
group_name: Foods for Infants and Young Children
description: Food products designed for children approximately 1-3 years old. Includes finger foods, small meals, and snacks formulated to meet the nutritional requirements and developing eating capabilities of toddlers and young children.

name: Infant formulae
group_name: Foods for Infants and Young Children
description: Manufactured food designed to simulate human breast milk for infant consumption. Available in powder, liquid concentrate, and ready-to-feed forms, formulated to provide complete nutrition for infants who are not breastfed or as supplemental feeding.

name: Dietary foods for special medical purposes
group_name: Foods for Infants and Young Children
description: Specialized food products designed for infants and children with specific medical conditions or nutritional requirements. Includes hypoallergenic formulas, metabolic formulas, and therapeutic foods for various medical needs.

name: Meat - bovine (beef, veal, cow)
description: Flesh from cattle, including adult beef cattle and younger veal calves. Available in numerous cuts with varying tenderness, fat content, and flavor profiles, used in diverse cooking methods from grilling steaks to slow-cooking stews.

name: Meat - caprine (goat, kid)
description: Flesh from goats of various ages. It has a distinctive flavor that's leaner than lamb, popular in Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, and South Asian cuisines, typically prepared in curries, stews, and roasted dishes.

name: Meat - equidae (horse)
description: Flesh from horses, consumed in various cultures particularly in parts of Europe, Asia, and South America. It's typically leaner than beef with a slightly sweet flavor, used in traditional dishes, steaks, and cured products in regions where it's culturally accepted.

name: Meat - ovine (lamb, mutton, sheep)
description: Flesh from sheep, with lamb from younger animals (under 12 months) and mutton from mature sheep. It has a distinctive flavor that strengthens with age, popular in Middle Eastern, European, and Indian cuisines in various preparations.

name: Meat - porcine (pork, pig)
description: Flesh from domesticated pigs, available in diverse cuts with varying fat content. Used in countless preparations worldwide from tender loins to fatty belly cuts, and as the base for many cured and processed meat products.

name: Meat - deer, including reindeer (venison)
description: Flesh from various species of deer including reindeer. It's typically very lean with a rich, gamey flavor stronger than beef but milder than other game meats, used in steaks, stews, sausages, and traditional dishes in many regions.

name: Meat - rabbit or hare
description: Flesh from domesticated rabbits or wild hares. It's very lean with a mild flavor (rabbit) or stronger gamey taste (hare), traditionally used in stews, pâtés, and braised dishes, particularly in European and North African cuisines.

name: Meat - amphibian
description: Flesh from edible amphibians, primarily frogs (frog legs). Has a mild flavor often compared to chicken with a delicate texture, popular in French, Asian, and Caribbean cuisines, typically prepared by frying, sautéing, or in soups.

name: Meat - reptile
description: Flesh from edible reptiles including alligator, crocodile, snake, and turtle. Each has distinct characteristics, with alligator and crocodile often described as a cross between chicken and fish, used in regional and specialty cuisines.

name: Meat - other, mixed or unspecified
description: Various other meats not specifically categorized elsewhere, including unusual game meats, exotic species, and products containing multiple meat types or where the specific meat source is not identified.

name: Meat products - pork hams (Parma, Serrano, Iberico, York etc.)
description: Cured pork leg products from various traditions. Includes dry-cured varieties like Italian Prosciutto di Parma, Spanish Jamón Serrano and Ibérico, and wet-cured products like York ham, each with distinctive flavor profiles and production methods.

name: Meat products - sausages (fuet, chorizo, salame etc.)
description: Ground meat products encased in natural or synthetic casings with various seasonings. Includes fresh sausages for cooking, cured varieties like Spanish chorizo, Italian salami, and Catalan fuet, with diverse flavors, textures, and regional variations.

name: Meat products and meat preparations - other
description: Various processed meat products not specifically categorized elsewhere. Includes pâtés, terrines, meat spreads, canned meat products, ready meals containing meat, and regional meat specialties from diverse culinary traditions.

name: Meat, minced, ground - bovine (beef, veal, cow)
description: Finely chopped beef or veal meat. Available in varying fat percentages, it's versatile and used in countless dishes including burgers, meatballs, meatloaf, bolognese sauce, and as a filling for various preparations worldwide.

name: Meat, minced, ground - ovine (lamb, mutton, sheep)
description: Finely chopped lamb or mutton meat. Has a distinctive flavor and is typically fattier than beef mince, commonly used in Middle Eastern, Mediterranean, and South Asian cuisines for kebabs, koftas, moussaka, and various stuffed dishes.

name: Meat, minced, ground - porcine (pork, pig)
description: Finely chopped pork meat available in varying fat ratios. Used in numerous dishes including many sausage varieties, meatballs, Chinese dumplings, larb in Southeast Asian cuisine, and as a component in mixed mince preparations.

name: Meat, minced, ground - equidae (horse)
description: Finely chopped horse meat, typically very lean with a slightly sweet flavor. Used in specific regional cuisines where horse meat is traditional, particularly in some European countries and parts of Asia, in preparations similar to beef mince.

name: Meat, minced, ground - mixed or unspecified
description: Finely chopped meat that contains a mixture of different meats or where the specific meat type is not identified. Often used in commercial products, budget preparations, and traditional recipes calling for mixed minces.

name: Offal - bovine (beef, veal, cow)
description: Organ meats and other non-muscle parts from cattle. Includes liver, heart, tongue, tripe (stomach), kidneys, sweetbreads (thymus/pancreas), and oxtail, used in traditional dishes worldwide from haute cuisine to rustic preparations.

name: Offal - caprine (goat, kid)
description: Organ meats and other non-muscle parts from goats. Includes liver, kidneys, intestines, and other organs used in various traditional dishes particularly in Middle Eastern, African, and South Asian cuisines where goat meat is common.

name: Offal - equidae (horse)
description: Organ meats and other non-muscle parts from horses. Consumed in cultures where horse meat is traditional, these include liver, heart, and other organs used in specific regional dishes in parts of Europe, Asia, and elsewhere.

name: Offal - ovine (lamb, mutton, sheep)
description: Organ meats and other non-muscle parts from sheep. Includes liver, kidneys, heart, brain, sweetbreads, and intestines (for sausage casings), featured in traditional dishes across Middle Eastern, European, and North African cuisines.

name: Offal - porcine (pork, pig)
description: Organ meats and other non-muscle parts from pigs. Includes liver, heart, chitlins (intestines), ears, feet, and head parts used in various preparations worldwide, from high-end pâtés to rustic dishes like head cheese and crackling.

name: Offal - deer, including reindeer
description: Organ meats and other non-muscle parts from deer species. Includes liver, heart, and other organs typically used in traditional hunting cuisines and by indigenous peoples in regions where deer are hunted or farmed.

name: Offal - rabbit or hare
description: Organ meats and other non-muscle parts from rabbits and hares. Includes liver, kidneys, and heart, often used in traditional rural cuisines, particularly in European countries where rabbit dishes are common.

name: Offal - mixed or unspecified
description: Organ meats and other non-muscle parts where the animal source is mixed or not specifically identified. Found in various prepared products, specialty dishes, and traditional preparations where multiple types of offal may be combined.

name: Meat - chicken
description: Meat from domesticated chickens, available with or without skin and bones. It has a mild flavor, relatively low fat content (especially breast meat), and is one of the most widely consumed meats globally, prepared in countless ways across world cuisines.

name: Meat - turkey
description: Meat from domesticated turkeys, with white breast meat and darker leg and thigh meat. It has a flavor similar to but slightly more pronounced than chicken, lower in fat than many meats, and is popular for holiday meals and as a healthier alternative to other meats.

name: Meat - duck
description: Meat from domesticated ducks with a higher fat content than chicken or turkey. It has a distinctive rich, somewhat gamey flavor, with prized breast meat and legs often used in confit. Popular in Chinese, French, and Southeast Asian cuisines.

name: Meat - goose
description: Meat from domesticated geese, with dark, rich, fatty flesh. It has a more intense flavor than duck, traditionally prepared whole for special occasions in European cuisines, with rendered fat highly prized for cooking potatoes and other foods.

name: Meat - guinea fowl
description: Meat from domesticated guinea fowl, with a flavor often described as between chicken and pheasant. It's leaner than chicken with slightly darker meat, popular in French and African cuisines for its gamey notes while remaining relatively mild.

name: Meat - pheasant
description: Meat from wild or farm-raised pheasants with a gamey flavor more pronounced than chicken but milder than many game birds. The breast meat is lean while the legs are darker and more flavorful, traditionally prepared in European hunting cuisines.

name: Meat - pigeon
description: Meat from domesticated pigeons (also called squab when young), with dark, tender flesh and a mild gamey flavor. Popular in Middle Eastern, North African, French, and Chinese cuisines, typically served whole due to the small size of the birds.

name: Meat - other game birds
description: Meat from various wild birds not categorized elsewhere, including quail, grouse, partridge, woodcock, and snipe. They typically have stronger gamey flavors than domesticated poultry, featured in high-end cuisine and traditional hunting dishes.

name: Poultry meat products - sausages
description: Processed sausages made primarily from poultry meats rather than traditional red meats. They include chicken and turkey sausages in various styles, often marketed as leaner alternatives to pork or beef sausages with diverse seasonings and flavor profiles.

name: Poultry meat products - other (pâté, burgers,  etc.)
description: Various processed poultry products not categorized elsewhere, including ground poultry burger patties, chicken or duck pâtés, pre-formed nuggets, strips, and other convenience items made primarily from poultry meat.

name: Meat, minced, ground - chicken
description: Finely chopped chicken meat, available in varying fat percentages. Leaner than most red meat alternatives, it's used in burgers, meatballs, dumplings, and as a lower-fat alternative in recipes traditionally calling for ground beef or pork.

name: Meat, minced, ground - turkey
description: Finely chopped turkey meat, typically very lean especially when made from breast meat. Often used as a healthier alternative to ground beef or pork in burgers, meatloaves, chili, tacos, and pasta sauces where its mild flavor readily absorbs seasonings.

name: Eggs
description: Whole eggs in shell, primarily from chickens but also from other poultry including ducks, quail, and geese. Versatile ingredients used in countless culinary applications from simple preparations to complex baking and as binding agents.

name: Eggs - dried/powdered/liquid
description: Processed egg products including dehydrated powdered eggs, liquid whole eggs, and separated egg components (whites/yolks). Used in commercial food production, baking applications, and for convenience in food service and certain home cooking uses.

name: Offal - chicken
description: Organ meats and other edible non-muscle parts from chickens. Includes liver, heart, gizzards, and feet, used in various cuisines worldwide from French pâtés to Asian soups and stir-fries, and as key ingredients in traditional dishes and stocks.

name: Offal - turkey
description: Organ meats and other edible non-muscle parts from turkeys. Includes liver, heart, and gizzards, often used in holiday stuffings and gravies in North American cuisine, and in various traditional preparations where turkey is common.

name: Offal - duck
description: Organ meats and other edible non-muscle parts from ducks. Includes liver (used for foie gras when specially produced), heart, gizzards, and feet. Duck liver is particularly prized in French cuisine, while other parts feature in Asian dishes.

name: Offal - goose
description: Organ meats and other edible non-muscle parts from geese. Includes liver (the traditional source of foie gras when specially fed), heart, and gizzards, with goose liver pâté being particularly valued in European haute cuisine.

name: Offal - pheasant
description: Organ meats and other edible non-muscle parts from pheasants. These include liver and heart, typically used in game pâtés, terrines, and traditional hunting cuisine preparations in European countries where pheasant hunting is common.

name: Offal - pidgeon
description: Organ meats and other edible non-muscle parts from pigeons. Includes liver, heart, and gizzards, often used in specialized dishes in cuisines where pigeon meat is traditional, particularly in Middle Eastern, North African, and French cooking.

name: Offal - other game birds
description: Organ meats and other edible non-muscle parts from various game birds not categorized elsewhere. Includes organs from quail, grouse, partridge and other wild fowl, used in traditional game recipes and high-end culinary preparations.

name: Meat - snails
description: Edible land snails, primarily from the Helix species, with tender meat and a mild, earthy flavor. Most famously prepared as escargot in French cuisine with garlic butter and herbs, but also featured in Mediterranean, North African, and Southeast Asian dishes.

name: Gelatine
description: A translucent, colorless, flavorless food ingredient derived from collagen obtained from animal body parts. Used as a gelling agent in desserts, confectionery, pharmaceuticals, and various food products to provide structure and texture.

name: Honey
description: Sweet, viscous substance produced by bees from flower nectar. Varies in color, flavor, and consistency depending on the floral source, used as a natural sweetener, in baking, as a spread, and for its potential antimicrobial and health benefits.

name: Royal jelly, bee pollen, propolis
description: Specialized bee products: royal jelly is the secretion fed to queen bee larvae, bee pollen is collected flower pollen, and propolis is a resinous mixture collected by bees. All are used as health supplements and in traditional medicine systems.

name: Bee larvae and other insects
description: Edible insects including bee larvae, crickets, grasshoppers, mealworms, and others. High in protein and nutrients, they're traditional foods in many cultures worldwide and increasingly promoted as sustainable future protein sources in Western countries.

name: Milk - bovine (cow)
description: Liquid milk from dairy cows, the most widely consumed animal milk globally. Available in various fat percentages from skim to whole, it's used as a beverage, cooking ingredient, and base for numerous dairy products across many world cuisines.

name: Milk - caprine (goat)
description: Liquid milk from dairy goats, with a slightly tangy flavor and higher digestibility than cow's milk for some people. Popular in Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, and African cuisines, used both as a beverage and in cheese and yogurt production.

name: Milk - ovine (sheep)
description: Liquid milk from dairy sheep, significantly higher in fat and protein than cow or goat milk. Rarely consumed as a beverage, it's primarily used to produce cheeses like Roquefort, Pecorino, and Feta, and yogurts in Mediterranean and Middle Eastern cuisines.

name: Milk products - condensed milk
description: Cow's milk with water content reduced and sugar added, creating a thick, sweet product with caramelized flavor. Used in desserts worldwide, as coffee sweetener in Southeast Asia, and as a baking ingredient in many cultures where fresh dairy is less available.

name: Milk products - cream
description: The high-fat layer skimmed from milk, available in various fat percentages from light (single) to heavy (double) cream. Used in cooking, baking, whipped as a dessert topping, in coffee, and as the base for many sauces, particularly in European cuisines.

name: Milk products - butter and ghee
description: Butter is a solid dairy fat made by churning cream; ghee is clarified butter with milk solids removed. Both have rich flavors and are used for cooking, baking, and as spreads, with ghee being particularly important in South Asian and Middle Eastern cuisines.

name: Milk products - cheese
description: Solid dairy products made by coagulating milk proteins, available in hundreds of varieties from soft to hard and mild to strong. Created through various aging and processing methods, cheese is used in countless dishes across global cuisines as both ingredient and standalone food.

name: Milk products - yoghurt
description: Fermented milk product created by bacterial fermentation of milk sugars, producing a thick, tangy food. Available in various styles from thin drinking yogurts to thick Greek and strained varieties, used as a breakfast food, snack, cooking ingredient, and in numerous traditional dishes.

name: Milk products - milk powder
description: Dehydrated milk created by removing water from liquid milk, available in whole, partially skimmed, and skimmed varieties. Has a long shelf life and is used in baking, confectionery, as a nutritional supplement, and for reconstituting into liquid milk where fresh is unavailable.

name: Milk products - whey powder
description: Dehydrated whey, the liquid remaining after milk has been curdled and strained in cheese-making. Rich in protein and lactose, it's used in protein supplements, animal feed, baked goods, processed foods, and as a nutritional additive in various products.

name: Milk products - ice-cream (& similar frozen confections)
description: Frozen dairy desserts made from cream, milk, sugar, and flavorings, churned while freezing to incorporate air. Includes traditional ice cream, gelato, frozen yogurt, and similar products in countless flavors, consumed as desserts and treats worldwide.

name: Milk products - milk-based beverages
description: Drinks with milk as the primary ingredient, including flavored milks, milkshakes, malted milk drinks, and similar beverages. Popular as nutritional supplements, treats, and meal replacements in various forms across different cultures and age groups.

name: Milk products - others (e.g. caseins)
description: Various other dairy derivatives not categorized elsewhere, including casein (milk protein used in food processing and as a binding agent), lactose, and other milk components extracted and used in food manufacturing, supplements, and specialized applications.

name: Fish - fresh/frozen
description: Fresh or frozen fish in whole, filleted, or portioned forms. Includes diverse species from both freshwater and saltwater environments, preserving the nutritional value and texture for various cooking methods from grilling to baking and steaming.

name: Fish - smoked/cured/dried or otherwise preserved
description: Fish preserved through smoking, salting, drying, or other traditional methods. Includes products like smoked salmon, salt cod, dried stockfish, and pickled herring, offering extended shelf life while developing distinctive flavors and textures.

name: Crustaceans (crab, shrimps, prawns etc.)
description: Marine arthropods with hard outer shells including crabs, lobsters, shrimp, and prawns. Available live, fresh, frozen, or pre-cooked, they have sweet, distinctive flavors and are considered delicacies in many cuisines worldwide.

name: Bivalve molluscs (mussels, clams, shellfish)
description: Marine and freshwater mollusks with hinged shells including mussels, clams, oysters, and scallops. They filter-feed, developing distinctive flavors based on their environment, and are served steamed, baked, fried, or raw in various global cuisines.

name: Cephalopods (octopus, squid etc.)
description: Marine mollusks including octopus, squid (calamari), and cuttlefish. They have tender flesh when properly prepared and feature prominently in Mediterranean, Asian, and coastal cuisines worldwide, served grilled, fried, in stews, or as sushi.

name: Seaweed, algae, carrageenan
description: Edible marine plants and algae including nori, kombu, wakame, and dulse. Used in East Asian cuisines for wrapping sushi, flavoring broths, in salads, and as thickening agents (carrageenan) in food production and commercial applications.

name: Surimi
description: Processed fish paste made from white-fleshed fish, shaped and flavored to resemble crab, lobster, or other seafood. Popular in Japanese cuisine as kamaboko and widely used in Western markets as imitation crab sticks in seafood salads and sushi.

name: Other sea food
description: Various aquatic foods not specifically categorized elsewhere, including sea urchins, sea cucumbers, jellyfish, and specialty regional seafood items with diverse culinary applications and traditional preparations across global cuisines.

name: Fat - bovine (beef, veal, cow)
description: Fat rendered from cattle, including suet (kidney fat) and tallow. Has a high smoke point and distinctive flavor, traditionally used for cooking, pastry making, and preserved products, particularly in European and American cuisines.

name: Fat - caprine (goat, kid)
description: Fat rendered from goats, less common than other animal fats but used in certain regional cuisines. It has a mild flavor compared to other ruminant fats and is used primarily in areas where goat meat is a dietary staple.

name: Fat - equidae (horse)
description: Fat rendered from horses, used in specific regional cuisines where horse meat is traditional. It has a distinctive flavor and texture, employed in traditional preparations primarily in parts of Central Asia and certain European regions.

name: Fat - ovine (lamb, mutton, sheep)
description: Fat rendered from sheep, including tallow and suet. It has a strong, distinctive flavor and is used in traditional cooking of Middle Eastern, Central Asian, and certain European cuisines, particularly for preservation and specific regional dishes.

name: Fat - porcine (pork, pig)
description: Fat rendered from pigs, including lard and leaf lard (from around the kidneys). It has a neutral flavor, creamy texture, and high smoke point, used in pastry making, frying, and as a spread in many European, Chinese, and Latin American cuisines.

name: Fat - deer, including reindeer
description: Fat rendered from various deer species including reindeer. Used in traditional cooking by indigenous peoples and in regional cuisines where venison is common, valued both for cooking and sometimes for medicinal or practical applications.

name: Fat - rabbit or hare
description: Fat rendered from rabbits or hares, typically collected during cooking rather than separately rendered. Used in traditional rural cuisines, particularly in Europe, to enhance flavor in dishes using the same meat or in preserved products.

name: Fat - chicken
description: Fat rendered from chickens, often collected from broths or roasting. It has a rich flavor ideal for enhancing poultry dishes, roasting vegetables, and making traditional Jewish schmaltz, used across various cuisines for its flavor profile.

name: Fat - turkey
description: Fat rendered from turkeys, typically collected during roasting or processing. Similar to chicken fat but with its own distinctive flavor, used primarily in holiday cooking and to enhance flavor in stuffings, gravies, and other poultry dishes.

name: Fat - duck
description: Fat rendered from ducks, prized in many cuisines for its rich flavor. It has a high smoke point and unique taste, used particularly in French cuisine for confit, roasting potatoes, and enhancing vegetables and other dishes.

name: Fat - goose
description: Fat rendered from geese, highly valued in European and Jewish cuisines. It has a rich flavor, buttery texture when melted, and high smoke point, traditionally used for preservation, confit, roasting, and as a spread on bread.

name: Fat - pheasant
description: Fat rendered from pheasants, less common than other poultry fats but used in game cookery. It has a distinctive gamey flavor that enhances similar dishes and is typically collected during cooking rather than separately rendered.

name: Fat - pigeon
description: Fat rendered from pigeons, used in specialized and traditional cooking where pigeon meat is common. It has a concentrated flavor and is typically used to enhance dishes featuring the same meat, particularly in Middle Eastern and French cuisine.

name: Fat - mixed animal fats
description: Blends of various animal fats combined for specific cooking purposes or commercial products. These mixtures may be created to achieve particular flavor profiles or functional properties for cooking, baking, or processed food production.

name: Milk fat
description: Fat derived from milk, primarily in the form of butter, ghee, and cream. It has a rich flavor, distinctive aroma, and is used widely in cooking, baking, and as spreads, with varying compositions and preparations across global cuisines.

name: Olive oil (excluding infused oils)
description: Oil pressed from olives, ranging from extra virgin (first cold press) to refined varieties. It has distinctive flavor profiles based on olive variety and production method, central to Mediterranean cuisines for cooking, dressing, and finishing dishes.

name: Palm oil
description: Oil derived from the fruit of oil palm trees, with high saturated fat content and reddish color in unrefined form. Used widely in commercial food production, traditional West African and Brazilian cuisines, and as a cooking oil in tropical regions.

name: Pepper oil
description: Oil infused with or extracted from various pepper varieties. Used primarily as a flavoring agent rather than a cooking medium, adding heat and pepper flavor to dishes, particularly in Asian cuisines and specialty condiments.

name: Rapeseed (canola) oil
description: Oil pressed from rapeseed/canola, with low saturated fat content and neutral flavor. It has a moderately high smoke point making it versatile for various cooking methods from sautéing to baking, widely used in commercial food production.

name: Soybean oil
description: Oil extracted from soybeans, with a neutral flavor and high smoke point. One of the most widely produced vegetable oils globally, used in commercial food production, for frying, and in various processed foods and dressings.

name: Sunflower oil
description: Oil pressed from sunflower seeds, available in high-oleic and standard varieties. It has a light flavor, golden color, and high smoke point, making it popular for frying, baking, and as a neutral-tasting ingredient in dressings and processed foods.

name: Other vegetable and fruit oils, fats and infused oils
description: Various oils from plant sources not specifically categorized elsewhere, including specialty oils like avocado, walnut, sesame, coconut, and flavored or infused oils with herbs, spices, or other ingredients for culinary applications.

name: Fish oil
description: Oil extracted from fatty fish like salmon, mackerel, and cod liver. Rich in omega-3 fatty acids, it's primarily used as a nutritional supplement rather than for cooking, though it features in traditional cuisines of some coastal communities.

name: Canned foods - fruit
description: Fruits preserved in cans or jars, typically in syrup, juice, or water. Includes various whole, sliced, or diced fruits with extended shelf life, used in desserts, as toppings, in baking, and as convenient fruit servings when fresh is unavailable.

name: Canned foods - meals
description: Complete or nearly complete prepared meals in cans, requiring minimal preparation. Includes stews, pasta dishes, chili, curried meals, and numerous other convenient food options designed for quick consumption with extended storage life.

name: Canned foods - meat
description: Processed meat products preserved in cans, including corned beef, ham, SPAM, chicken, and various meat spreads. These provide convenient protein sources with long shelf life, used in sandwiches, as emergency supplies, and in various prepared dishes.

name: Canned foods - seafood
description: Seafood preserved in cans, including tuna, salmon, sardines, anchovies, and shellfish. These products offer convenient protein sources with extended shelf life, used in salads, sandwiches, pasta dishes, and as standalone protein servings.

name: Canned foods - soups
description: Prepared soups in cans, ranging from clear broths to chunky stews and cream-based varieties. These convenience foods require minimal preparation, typically just heating, and come in countless varieties from traditional to international flavors.

name: Canned foods - vegetables
description: Vegetables preserved in cans, typically pre-cooked in water or brine. Includes corn, green beans, peas, carrots, mixed vegetables, and specialty items, providing convenient vegetable options with extended shelf life for side dishes and recipe ingredients.

name: Canned foods - other
description: Various canned food products not specifically categorized elsewhere, including beans, pasta products, specialty ethnic foods, desserts, and other preserved items with extended shelf life and convenient preparation requirements.

name: Canned beverages
description: Drinks packaged in aluminum or steel cans, including sodas, energy drinks, coffee beverages, alcoholic beverages, and juices. The canning process provides portability, extended shelf life, protection from light, and quick cooling capabilities.

name: Apple juice & concentrate
description: Juice extracted from apples, available as ready-to-drink liquid or in concentrated form requiring dilution. It ranges from clear to cloudy in appearance with sweet-tart flavor profiles depending on apple varieties used and processing methods.

name: Orange juice & concentrate
description: Juice extracted from oranges, available fresh, pasteurized, or as frozen concentrate. It has a bright citrus flavor with varying sweetness and acidity levels depending on orange varieties and seasonality, high in vitamin C and widely consumed globally.

name: Other or mixed fruit juices
description: Juices from fruits other than apples and oranges, or blends of multiple fruit juices. Includes varieties like grape, cranberry, pineapple, and mixed fruit blends, offering diverse flavor profiles and nutritional benefits.

name: Other concentrated fruit juices
description: Fruit juices with water content reduced through evaporation, requiring dilution before consumption. These shelf-stable products include concentrates from various fruits excluding apple and orange, used both as beverages and as ingredients in food production.

name: Vegetable juices
description: Juices extracted from vegetables, most commonly tomato, carrot, beetroot, and greens. They typically have less sugar than fruit juices with more savory flavor profiles, consumed as beverages and used in cooking or as cocktail ingredients.

name: Fruit nectars
description: Beverage products made from fruit puree or juice with added water and often sweeteners. With lower fruit content than 100% juice, nectars are typically made from fruits that are too pulpy or tart to be consumed as straight juice, like peach, pear, or apricot.

name: Fruit-flavoured soft drinks (not canned)
description: Non-alcoholic carbonated or still beverages with fruit flavoring but minimal or no actual fruit juice, typically containing water, sweeteners, and flavorings. Packaged in bottles or other non-canned containers with various fruit flavor profiles.

name: Fruit-flavoured alcoholic drinks (not canned)
description: Alcoholic beverages flavored with fruit or fruit extracts, including fruit-flavored wine coolers, hard seltzers, alcopops, and flavored spirits. These beverages typically contain lower alcohol content than traditional spirits, with sweet fruit flavors that mask the alcohol taste.

name: Wines (red, white, rose, sparkling, fortified)
description: Alcoholic beverages produced through fermentation of grape juice, with styles including red (from dark grapes with skins), white (without skins), rosé (limited skin contact), sparkling (carbonated), and fortified (with added spirits). Flavor profiles range widely based on grape variety, terroir, and production method.

name: Beers (not canned)
description: Alcoholic beverages produced through fermentation of cereal grains, typically barley malt, with hops added for flavor and preservation. Available in countless styles from light lagers to dark stouts, packaged in bottles or kegs rather than cans.

name: Cider, perry (not canned)
description: Alcoholic beverages produced through fermentation of apple juice (cider) or pear juice (perry). They range from dry to sweet with varying carbonation levels, packaged in bottles or other non-canned formats, popular in European countries and increasingly worldwide.

name: Mead
description: One of the oldest alcoholic beverages, produced by fermenting honey with water, sometimes with added fruits, spices, or grains. It ranges from sweet to dry with alcohol content typically between wine and beer, with historical significance in many cultures worldwide.

name: Spirits and liqueurs
description: Distilled alcoholic beverages with higher alcohol content than fermented drinks. Spirits include vodka, whiskey, rum, and gin, while liqueurs are sweetened and flavored spirits often consumed as digestifs or in cocktails, with diverse flavor profiles from herbs, fruits, nuts, and spices.

name: Mineral water
description: Natural water containing minerals and trace elements from underground sources. It may be still or carbonated (naturally or artificially), with mineral content creating distinct flavor profiles ranging from soft to notably mineral-rich depending on source and filtration.

name: Water intended for human consumption
description: Potable water processed and packaged specifically for drinking purposes. Includes spring water, purified water, and tap water that has been treated to ensure safety and palatability, often with minerals added or removed to achieve desired taste profiles.

name: Soluble coffee (instant coffee)
description: Coffee product created by brewing coffee and then dehydrating it through freeze-drying or spray-drying. It dissolves quickly in hot water for convenient preparation without equipment, available in various roast levels and sometimes with added flavors or whiteners.

name: Other beverages (not canned) - liquid
description: Various liquid beverages not specifically categorized elsewhere and not in canned format. Includes energy drinks, sports drinks, plant-based milks, kombucha, drinking yogurts, and specialty or regional beverages from diverse traditions worldwide.

name: Other beverages (not canned) - powder
description: Dehydrated beverage products requiring reconstitution with water before consumption. Includes powdered fruit drinks, hot chocolate mixes, protein shakes, powdered tea beverages, and other drink mixes offering convenience, extended shelf life, and portability.

name: Hydrolysed vegetable protein
description: Protein derived from vegetables (typically soy, corn, or wheat) broken down into amino acids through acid, enzyme, or bacterial treatments. Used as a flavor enhancer and umami agent in processed foods, soups, sauces, and as a savory base in vegetarian products.

name: Soy sauce
description: Fermented condiment made from soybeans, wheat, salt, and water. It has a distinctive dark color and savory umami flavor, essential in East Asian cuisines and increasingly used worldwide as a seasoning and flavor enhancer in diverse culinary applications.

name: Jams, jellies and marmalades and other processed fruit-based foods
description: Sweet preserved fruit products with varying textures: jams contain fruit pieces, jellies are clear and smooth, marmalades incorporate citrus peel. Also includes fruit butters, preserves, and similar fruit spreads used on breads, in pastries, and as condiments.

name: Sugar-based confectionery
description: Sweet food products primarily made from sugar or similar sweeteners. Includes hard candies, caramels, lollipops, marshmallows, gummies, fudge, and similar confections without chocolate as the main ingredient, with diverse flavors and textures.

name: Chocolate-based confectionery (except spreads)
description: Sweet food products where chocolate is the primary ingredient. Includes chocolate bars, truffles, bonbons, chocolate-covered nuts or fruits, and similar products with various fillings and additions, excluding spreadable chocolate products like Nutella.

name: Confectionery - other
description: Sweet food products not specifically categorized elsewhere. Includes licorice, Turkish delight, halva, specialty regional sweets, sugar-free confections, functional candies (with supplements/herbs), and hybrid confection types that don't fit standard categories.

name: Vinegar
description: Acidic liquid produced by fermenting alcohol from various sources. Includes wine vinegar, apple cider vinegar, malt vinegar, rice vinegar, and balsamic vinegar, used in cooking, pickling, salad dressings, and food preservation across global cuisines.

name: Mustard
description: Condiment made from ground mustard seeds mixed with liquids and seasonings. Ranges from mild yellow American mustard to spicy Dijon and whole-grain varieties, used in sandwiches, as a cooking ingredient, in dressings, and as a condiment worldwide.

name: Pickles, chutney (various, usually in jars)
description: Preserved foods typically in vinegar, brine, or sugar solutions. Pickles are fermented or vinegar-preserved vegetables, while chutneys are spicy-sweet condiments made from fruits or vegetables, commonly used as condiments, sides, and flavor enhancers.

name: Tomato sauce, paste, puree, tomatade, ketchup
description: Tomato-based products with varying consistencies and purposes. Sauce is liquid, paste is highly concentrated, puree is between these, tomatade is richly flavored, and ketchup includes vinegar and sweeteners, all used in cooking or as condiments.

name: Other sauces (various, usually in jars)
description: Various prepared sauce products not specifically categorized elsewhere. Includes pasta sauces, curry sauces, stir-fry sauces, barbecue sauces, hot sauces, and regional specialties from diverse culinary traditions, typically in jarred or bottled format.

name: Soups (chilled)
description: Ready-to-eat liquid food preparations stored in refrigerated conditions. Includes both hot-served soups requiring heating and cold soups intended to be served chilled like gazpacho or vichyssoise, typically with shorter shelf life than shelf-stable soups.

name: Soup mixes (dry)
description: Dehydrated soup ingredients requiring reconstitution with water or other liquids. Includes bouillon cubes, powdered soup bases, dried soup with vegetables/pasta/rice, and instant soup cups, offering convenience, extended shelf life, and quick preparation.

name: Spreads and similar foods (except meat or nut)
description: Semi-solid food products designed for spreading, excluding meat pastes and nut butters. Includes vegetable-based spreads like hummus, cheese spreads, chocolate spreads, sandwich spreads, and vegetarian alternatives used on bread, crackers, and in cooking.

name: Liquorice extract
description: Concentrated extract from the roots of the licorice plant (Glycyrrhiza glabra). It has a distinctive sweet flavor much stronger than refined sugar, used as a flavoring in candies, beverages, medicines, and as a food additive in various preparations.

name: Frozen ready meals
description: Complete prepared dishes preserved by freezing for later consumption. Includes diverse meal options from various cuisines requiring minimal preparation beyond heating, designed for convenience with extended storage life in home freezers.

name: Part-cooked chilled ready meals
description: Partially prepared dishes stored in refrigerated conditions requiring final cooking before consumption. These products offer a balance between convenience and freshness, with shorter shelf life than frozen options but often better texture and flavor profiles.

name: Prepared fresh fruit (single or mixed)
description: Fresh fruit that has been washed, peeled, cut, or otherwise prepared for immediate consumption. Includes single-type fruit preparations and mixed fruit salads, typically packaged in plastic containers for convenience and sold in refrigerated sections of stores.

name: Prepared fresh vegetables (veg spagetti etc)
description: Fresh vegetables that have been washed, peeled, cut, or transformed for convenient use. Includes pre-cut vegetables, vegetable noodles (like zucchini spirals), stir-fry mixes, and ready-to-cook vegetable preparations designed to reduce meal preparation time.

name: Gluten-free products
description: Food products specifically formulated to exclude gluten-containing ingredients for those with celiac disease or gluten sensitivity. Includes gluten-free versions of typically wheat-based foods like breads, pastas, cereals, and baked goods using alternative flours and ingredients.

name: Other prepared foods
description: Various ready-to-eat or minimally-prepared food products not specifically categorized elsewhere. Includes specialty items, ethnic foods, meal components, and novel food preparations that don't fit into standard categories but offer convenience or specific culinary functions.

name: Snack foods
description: Ready-to-eat food items designed for consumption between meals. Includes potato chips, pretzels, popcorn, rice cakes, extruded snacks, meat snacks, and similar products characterized by convenience, portability, and typically longer shelf life than fresh foods.

name: Dry ingredient mixes (batter, breading, custard, muffin etc.) and dough
description: Premixed dry ingredients requiring addition of liquids or other components before cooking. Includes cake mixes, pancake mixes, coating mixes for meats, dessert mixes, and similar products designed to simplify cooking processes while providing consistent results.

name: Sugars - as defined in Directive 2001/111/EC, treacle, molasses and other sugars
description: Crystalline sucrose and other sweetening agents from various sources. Includes refined white sugar, brown sugar, raw sugar, treacle, molasses, and other sugar products defined by European regulations, used for sweetening, preservation, and texture in food preparation.

name: Sugars - syrups, flavoured syrups and similar products
description: Liquid sweeteners including plain and flavored sugar syrups. Encompasses maple syrup, corn syrup, glucose syrup, flavored coffee syrups, and similar products used to sweeten beverages and foods, as toppings, and in various culinary applications worldwide.

name: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C)
description: A water-soluble vitamin and antioxidant added to foods as a nutrient supplement and preservative. It helps prevent browning in fruits and vegetables, acts as a dough conditioner in baked goods, and extends shelf life in many processed foods while providing nutritional benefits.

name: Chemicals excl. colourings, enzymes & flavourings
description: Various chemical substances added to foods for functional purposes other than coloring, enzymatic activity, or flavoring. Includes preservatives, emulsifiers, stabilizers, thickeners, acidity regulators, anti-caking agents, and other food additives that improve texture, shelf life, or processing properties.

name: Colourings other than synthetic colourings
description: Natural or nature-derived substances added to foods to enhance or change color. Includes extracts from plants, vegetables, and fruits such as carotenoids, anthocyanins, chlorophyll, paprika extract, and caramel coloring, increasingly preferred by consumers seeking 'clean label' products.

name: Synthetic colourings
description: Artificially created colorants added to foods to enhance appearance or replace color lost during processing. These include azo dyes like tartrazine and other laboratory-synthesized colors that provide consistent, stable, and often intense coloration to various food products.

name: Enzymes
description: Proteins that catalyze biochemical reactions, added to foods for specific functions. Used in baking (amylases, proteases), cheese production (rennet), meat tenderization (papain), fruit juice clarification (pectinases), and numerous other applications to improve quality, texture, and processing efficiency.

name: Natural flavourings
description: Flavor compounds extracted from plants, animals, or microbiological sources. These include essential oils, extracts, distillates, and other isolated components that provide characteristic tastes and aromas to foods without being primarily consumed as foods themselves.

name: Synthetic flavourings
description: Laboratory-created flavor compounds that mimic natural flavors or create novel taste experiences. These provide consistent flavor profiles, often at lower cost than natural alternatives, and are widely used in processed foods, beverages, and confectionery products.

name: Salt (including sea salt and flavoured salts)
description: Sodium chloride in various forms used as a flavor enhancer, preservative, and functional ingredient. Includes refined table salt, minimally processed sea salt, Himalayan salt, and specialty flavored salts infused with herbs, spices, or other flavorings for culinary applications.

name: Nangai nuts (Canarium indicum L.)
description: Nuts from the canarium tree native to Pacific Islands, with a flavor similar to almonds. Classified as a novel food in some jurisdictions, these nutrient-rich nuts are traditionally consumed in their native regions and increasingly available in global markets as specialty ingredients.

name: Noni juice
description: Juice extracted from the fruit of the Morinda citrifolia tree native to Southeast Asia and Pacific Islands. It has a distinctive strong flavor and odor, marketed primarily as a health supplement for its purported benefits, though scientific evidence for many claims remains limited.

name: Stevia rebaudiana Bertoni
description: A natural sweetener derived from the leaves of the stevia plant native to South America. It contains steviol glycosides that are hundreds of times sweeter than sugar with minimal calories, used as a sugar substitute in beverages, foods, and as a tabletop sweetener.

name: Other novel foods
description: Various foods and ingredients that do not have a significant history of consumption in a region before May 15, 1997 (EU definition). Includes emerging superfoods, algae products, insects for human consumption, lab-grown proteins, and other innovative food sources requiring regulatory approval.

name: Food and dietary supplements
description: Products intended to supplement the diet by providing nutrients or other substances with nutritional or physiological effects. Includes vitamins, minerals, herbs, amino acids, and enzyme supplements in various forms such as capsules, tablets, powders, and liquid extracts.

name: Feed materials - animal products
description: Materials derived from animal sources for use in animal feeds. Includes processed animal proteins, blood products, gelatin, and other animal-derived ingredients that provide protein, fats, and essential nutrients in livestock and pet food formulations.

name: Feed materials - cereal-based
description: Feed components derived from cereal grains including wheat, barley, oats, and rice. These provide carbohydrates, fiber, and some protein in animal diets, serving as energy sources and bulking agents in various feed formulations for livestock and other animals.

name: Feed materials - crustaceans
description: Feed ingredients derived from crustaceans such as shrimp, crab, and krill. These materials are rich in protein, chitin, and minerals, primarily used in aquaculture feeds and specialty pet foods, often processed into meals or hydrolysates.

name: Feed materials - fish meal
description: Processed, dried, and ground tissue of undecomposed whole fish or fish cuttings. High in protein (typically 60-72%) and rich in omega-3 fatty acids, minerals, and vitamins, primarily used in aquaculture feeds and as a protein supplement in other animal diets.

name: Feed materials - groundnuts
description: Peanuts and peanut by-products used in animal feeds. Peanut meal, a by-product of oil extraction, contains approximately 45-55% protein and is used as a protein supplement in livestock diets, though requiring careful monitoring for aflatoxin contamination.

name: Feed materials - maize & corn meal
description: Ground corn products used as energy sources in animal feeds. Rich in carbohydrates and containing moderate protein levels, these materials form a staple ingredient in many livestock feeds, particularly for poultry and swine due to their high digestibility and palatability.

name: Feed materials - milk & whey
description: Dairy-derived feed ingredients including dried milk powder, whey powder, and whey protein concentrates. These highly digestible protein sources are rich in essential amino acids and lactose, primarily used in feeds for young animals such as calves, piglets, and kittens.

name: Feed materials - palm products
description: By-products of palm oil processing used in animal feeds. Includes palm kernel meal and palm oil, with the meal providing protein (14-20%) and high fiber content, while palm oil serves as an energy-dense fat source in ruminant and monogastric animal diets.

name: Feed materials - poultry & feather meal
description: Rendered and processed poultry by-products and hydrolyzed feathers. Poultry meal contains 55-65% protein while feather meal can contain up to 85% protein, though with less digestibility unless properly hydrolyzed, used primarily in aquaculture feeds and pet foods.

name: Feed materials - rapeseed & meal
description: By-products of canola/rapeseed oil extraction. The resulting meal contains 35-40% protein with a good amino acid profile, used as a protein supplement in livestock feeds, particularly for cattle due to its relatively high fiber content and ruminal bypass protein.

name: Feed materials - soy beans & meal
description: Soybean products used in animal feeds, primarily soybean meal from oil extraction. With protein content of 44-48%, excellent amino acid profile, and high digestibility, it's the most widely used protein supplement in livestock and poultry feeds worldwide.

name: Feed materials - sugar beet pulp
description: Fibrous residue remaining after sugar extraction from sugar beets. Rich in highly digestible fiber and pectins, it's used primarily in ruminant diets as a digestible fiber source that promotes rumen health, and in horse feeds for its low starch content and digestibility.

name: Feed materials - sunflower seed & meal
description: By-products of sunflower oil production used in animal feeds. The meal contains 28-42% protein depending on processing methods, with high fiber content and good amino acid profile except for lysine, used in various livestock diets particularly for ruminants and horses.

name: Feed materials - other
description: Various other materials used in animal feeds not specifically categorized elsewhere. Includes alternative protein sources like insect meal, algae, yeast products, legume seeds, root crops, fruit pomaces, and other ingredients used for their nutritional or functional properties.

name: Feed additives
description: Substances added to animal feeds in small quantities for specific functions. Includes vitamins, minerals, amino acids, enzymes, probiotics, prebiotics, acidifiers, antioxidants, and other functional ingredients that enhance nutrition, improve feed efficiency, or promote animal health.

name: Complementary feed
description: Feed mixtures designed to supplement other feeds or forages in animal diets. These products contain concentrated levels of specific nutrients (proteins, minerals, vitamins) to balance nutritional deficiencies in the base diet, particularly important in ruminant livestock production systems.

name: Complete feed, pet food
description: Nutritionally complete formulations that meet all dietary requirements for companion animals. Includes dry kibble, wet foods, and semi-moist products for dogs, cats, and other pets, formulated to provide balanced nutrition without requiring supplementation from other food sources.

name: Premixtures for use in feed
description: Concentrated mixtures of vitamins, minerals, and other additives designed to be incorporated into feeds. These highly concentrated products are blended with base ingredients during feed manufacturing to ensure proper distribution of micronutrients and additives throughout the final feed.

name: Compound feed
description: Mixtures of multiple feed ingredients formulated for specific animal species and production stages. These balanced feeds combine energy sources, proteins, fiber, vitamins, and minerals in proportions that optimize animal performance, health, and production efficiency across livestock, poultry, and aquaculture.

name: Ceramic articles
description: Dishes, containers, and utensils made from fired clay materials used for food service and storage. Subject to regulations regarding potential lead and cadmium leaching, these include tableware, cookware, and storage containers that come into direct contact with food during preparation, serving, or storage.

name: Nylon articles
description: Food contact materials made from polyamide (nylon) polymers. Includes kitchen utensils, food processing equipment parts, and packaging materials valued for their durability and heat resistance, subject to regulations regarding potential migration of monomers and additives into food.

name: Melamine articles
description: Food service items made from melamine-formaldehyde resin, typically lightweight, break-resistant dishware and serving pieces. Regulated for potential formaldehyde and melamine migration, particularly when exposed to acidic foods or high temperatures, despite being marketed as durable alternatives to ceramic tableware.

name: Other articles
description: Various materials not specified elsewhere that come into contact with food. Includes items made from plastics, glass, metals, silicones, paper, bamboo composites, and other materials used in food packaging, processing, storage, and service, all subject to migration and safety regulations.

name: General information
description: Broad category covering general food-related information not specifically tied to individual commodities. Includes regulatory guidance, food safety principles, nutritional concepts, processing technologies, storage recommendations, and other general knowledge pertinent to food production, distribution, and consumption.
